{{Infobox storm | name = 1984 Barneveld, Wisconsin, tornado outbreak | image = Barneveld tornado damage.jpg | alt = | caption = F5 tornado damage in [[Barneveld, Wisconsin]] (Courtesy of NWS Milwaukee) | type = Tornado outbreak | active = June 7–8, 1984 | lowest pressure = | lowest temperature = | tornadoes = 46 | fujitascale = F5 | tornado duration = ~12 hours | highest winds = | hail = | gusts = | maximum snow = | power outages = | total fatalities = 13 fatalities, 322 injuries | damages = $40 million in Wisconsin alone (1984 [[United States dollar|USD]]){{Cite web |url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~storms |title=NCDC Storm Events-Select State |access-date=2008-01-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110505093502/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwEvent~Storms |archive-date=2011-05-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }} | affected = [[Midwestern United States]] | current advisories = | enhanced = | notes = }} The '''1984 Barneveld, Wisconsin, tornado outbreak''' is a significant severe weather and tornado event that took place across the central [[United States]] from [[North Dakota]] to [[Kansas]] on June 7–8, 1984. The [[tornado outbreak]] produced several significant tornadoes including an [[List of F5 and EF5 tornadoes|F5]] [[tornado]]{{cite book |last1=Grazulis |first1=Thomas P. |title=Significant Tornadoes 1680-1991: A Chronology and Analysis of Events |date=1993 |publisher=Environmental Films |location=St. Johnsbury, Vermont |isbn=1-879362-03-1 |pages=1257-1260}}"On the original Fujita scale [F0-F5], the damage generated by an F5 tornado corresponded to estimated wind speeds of 262 to 317 mph. However, research has shown that these estimated wind speeds may be over-exaggerated. As of 2007, any tornado that creates damage corresponding to estimated wind speeds of 200 mph or greater [on the Enhanced Fujita Scale] is classified as an EF5 tornado." https://weather.com/tv/shows/tornado-week/news/ef5-f5-most-violent-tornadoes-20140430 which traveled through [[Barneveld, Wisconsin]], in the early hours of June 8, 1984. The entire outbreak killed at least 13 people across three states including 9 in Barneveld alone. ==Meteorological synopsis== A [[low pressure system]] entered the Midwestern United States on June 7, 1984, and intensified while bringing a surge of moist and humid air coming from the [[Gulf of Mexico]]. After most of the affected areas were hit by a [[Mesoscale Convective Complex]] earlier during the morning of June 7, the unstable atmosphere, as well as [[wind shear]] and high [[Convective available potential energy|CAPE values]] produced a favorable environment for the development of extensive severe weather with possible tornadoes.http://www.aos.wisc.edu/uwaosjournal/Volume1/AOS453/FCS_Harrington.pdf Starting at around mid-afternoon, it started to produce several tornadoes across southern [[Minnesota]] and northwestern and southern [[Iowa]] including three F3s and a long-track F4 which traveled over 130 miles from extreme northern [[Missouri]] to southwest of [[Iowa City, Iowa|Iowa City]]. That tornado killed 3 people including one in Missouri's [[Harrison County, Missouri|Harrison County]]. Another person was killed in [[Ringgold County, Iowa|Ringgold County]] in Iowa by an F2 tornado at around 9:00 PM [[Central Daylight Time|CDT]]. Activity continued through the overnight hours as a new cluster of storms developed across [[Wisconsin]] near the Iowa and [[Illinois]] borders and produced strong tornadoes including the Barneveld tornado up until the early [[morning]] hours of June 8, 1984, before dissipating. Straight-line winds in excess of 100 mph and very large hail were also reported in eastern Iowa from the storm that went on to drop the tornado in Barneveld, Wisconsin. ==Tornadoes confirmed== {{Tornado Chart | Total=46 | F0=4 | F1=13 | F2=23 | F3=4 | F4=1 | F5=1 }} {| class="wikitable collapsible" width="100%" !colspan="6"|Confirmed tornadoes - June 7–8, 1984 |- |'''

(0.16 km) | |- |colspan="7" |Sources:[http://www.tornadohistoryproject.com/tornado/1984/6/7/table Tornado History Project (June 7, 1984)], [http://www.tornadohistoryproject.com/custom/256970/table Tornado History Project (June 8, 1984) - for Wisconsin data only], Grazulis (1984) |} ==The Barneveld Tornado== As the tornado activity calmed down across Iowa and Minnesota in which numerous strong to severe tornadoes struck those areas from mid-afternoon to mid-evening, the severe weather shifted east towards Wisconsin after dark where a tornado watch was issued at about 11:00 PM CDT. By this time, most of the residents of [[Barneveld, Wisconsin|Barneveld]] had gone to bed and were unaware of the tornado watch. A [[supercell]] [[thunderstorm]], which affected portions of southeastern Iowa with a few tornadoes at around 9:00 PM CDT before weakening and intensifying shortly after, entered Wisconsin from the Iowa/Illinois border at around 12:00 AM CDT near [[Dubuque, Iowa|Dubuque]]. Shortly after 12:30 AM CDT, June 8, it produced its first tornado near [[Belmont, Wisconsin|Belmont]] in [[Lafayette County, Wisconsin|Lafayette County]] and lifted near [[Mineral Point, Wisconsin|Mineral Point]] in [[Iowa County, Wisconsin|Iowa County]] about fifteen miles southwest of Barneveld. A few minutes later, this storm system produced one of the few F5 tornados to hit Wisconsin, developing northeast of Mineral Point (five to six miles southwest of Barneveld). At 12:41 CDT this F5 tornado drove through the center of Barneveld in full force, finally dissipating in northern [[Dane County, Wisconsin|Dane County]] around 1:40 AM CDT after traveling 36 miles (62 kilometers) for 59 minutes.{{cite web|title=June 8, 1984, Barneveld, WI F5 Tornado|url=http://www.weather.gov/mkx/060884-barneveld-tor|website=National Weather Service|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=30 July 2015}} A sharp bolt of [[lightning]] followed by a deafening clap of [[thunder]] cut the electricity to the town just a few minutes before the tornado struck Barneveld, awakened many residents. (It is said that the loss of power prevented the [[tornado siren]] from being activated prior to its arrival. In actuality, the town did not have a distinctive [[tornado siren]] from the siren used to activate the town's volunteer fire and EMT squad. If a siren had been activated, the residents would not have known it was a tornado warning.) At its peak, the tornado was nearly a quarter-mile wide. Other tornadoes rated from F1 to F3 touched down from [[Columbia County, Wisconsin|Columbia County]] to [[Dodge County, Wisconsin|Dodge County]] until after 3:00 AM CDT when activity finally weakened. [[Image:Barneveld tornado track.gif|right|thumb|300px|Tornado track of the Barneveld tornado (Courtesy of NWS [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin|Milwaukee]])]] The tornado was responsible for nine deaths and nearly 200 injuries in Barneveld while causing about $25 million in damage. In total, all three churches (the Congregational United Church of Christ, the Lutheran Church, and the Roman Catholic Church), 93 homes were destroyed as well as 17 businesses out of the town's 18, including the library, municipal building, fire station, bank, and post office. The village's water tower, though damaged, was not toppled by the winds. In addition, 64 other homes were badly damaged. The F5 damage occurred at a cul-de-sac on the northeast side of town. A cluster of several newly built homes were completely swept away at this location. Trees were debarked and vehicles were thrown and mangled. The Lutheran Church was completely leveled as well.http://extremeplanet.me/2012/11/27/the-indefinitive-list-of-the-strongest-tornadoes-ever-recorded-part-iv/ Some of the debris including paper work were later found about 135 miles away from the village. Eight homes were also destroyed in [[Black Earth, Wisconsin|Black Earth]], and 24 additional homes were destroyed between Barneveld and Black Earth. Other tornadoes in Wisconsin caused two additional injuries and about $15 million worth of damage but no additional fatalities.[http://www.crh.noaa.gov/mkx/document/tor/060884.php NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan, WI][http://www.channel3000.com/news/3395188/detail.html Barneveld, 1984: 9 Dead, 200 Injured - News Story - WISC Madison] {{webarchive|url=http://www.channel3000.com/news/3395188/detail.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927014820/http://www.channel3000.com/news/3395188/detail.html|dead-url=yes|date=September 27, 2007 }} The National Weather Service in Madison reported the next day that the frequency of lightning flashes in the storm visible from Madison exceeded 200 per minute, the flashes running together into a strobe-like effect, as mentioned in media reports and books about the disaster.''Extreme Weather'', pp 188 The Barneveld tornado was more particular as it was one of the rare tornadoes to occur during the overnight hours well after sunset although EF5/F5 tornadoes have occurred elsewhere during night, including more recently in [[Greensburg, Kansas]], on [[May 2007 Tornado Outbreak|May 4, 2007]] as well as in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], in [[Birmingham Tornado of April 1998|April 1998]], downtown [[Lubbock, Texas]], in [[Lubbock Tornado|1970]], [[Tanner, Alabama]], and [[Guin, Alabama]], in [[1974 Super Outbreak|1974]] and [[Udall, Kansas]], in [[1955 Great Plains tornado outbreak|1955]], the last being the deadliest Kansas tornado ever with over 80 deaths. {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0 0 0.5em 1em;float:right;" |+'''Outbreak death toll''' |- !'''State''' !'''Total''' !'''County''' !'''County
total''' |- |rowspan=3 bgcolor="#e6e9ff"|[[Iowa]] |rowspan=3 bgcolor="#e6e9ff"|'''3''' |[[Keokuk County, Iowa|Keokuk]] |1 |- |[[Mahaska County, Iowa|Mahaska]] |1 |- |[[Ringgold County, Iowa|Ringgold]] |1 |- |rowspan=1 bgcolor="#e6e9ff"|[[Missouri]] |rowspan=1 bgcolor="#e6e9ff"|'''1''' |[[Harrison County, Missouri|Harrison]] |1 |- |rowspan=1 bgcolor="#e6e9ff"|[[Wisconsin]] |rowspan=1 bgcolor="#e6e9ff"|'''9''' |[[Iowa County, Wisconsin|Iowa]] |9 |- |bgcolor="#e6e9ff"|Totals |bgcolor="#e6e9ff"|'''13''' |colspan=2| |- |colspan=4 align=center| All deaths were tornado-related |- |} The Barneveld tornado was the first F5 in Wisconsin since the 1958 [[1958 Colfax, Wisconsin, tornado outbreak|Colfax Tornado]], which killed 21. It was the first F5 in the US since 2 April 1982 when one touched down near [[Broken Bow, Oklahoma]]; the next one occurred on 31 May 1985 in [[Wheatland, Pennsylvania]], during the [[1985 United States-Canadian tornado outbreak]]. The [[Oakfield Tornado]] of 18 July 1996, the most recent F5 in Wisconsin, did not cause any fatalities. ==See also== * [[Barneveld, Wisconsin]] * [[List of North American tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] * [[List of F5 and EF5 tornadoes]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.crh.noaa.gov/mkx/document/tor/060884.php Summary of the Barneveld tornado and supercell] (NWS Milwaukee) * [http://www.aos.wisc.edu/uwaosjournal/Volume1/AOS453/FCS_Harrington.pdf Analysis of the Barneveld Tornado] (by Alex Harrington) {{Wisconsin tornado events}} {{1984 tornado outbreaks}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1984 Barneveld, Wisconsin Tornado Outbreak}} [[Category:F5 tornadoes]] [[Category:Tornadoes of 1984]] [[Category:Tornadoes in Iowa]] [[Category:Tornadoes in Kansas]] [[Category:Tornadoes in Missouri]] [[Category:Tornadoes in Minnesota]] [[Category:Tornadoes in North Dakota]] [[Category:Tornadoes in South Dakota]] [[Category:Tornadoes in Wisconsin]] [[Category:1984 natural disasters in the United States|Barneveld, Wisconsin Tornado Outbreak, 1984]] [[Category:June 1984 events]]

The '''2010 Boston Water Emergency''' occurred on May 1, 2010, when a water pipe in [[Weston, Massachusetts|Weston]], [[Massachusetts]], broke and began flooding into the [[Charles River]]. This led to unsanitary water conditions in the [[greater Boston area]], which resulted in [[Governor]] [[Deval Patrick]] declaring a state of emergency and an [[Boil-water advisory|order for residents to boil drinking water]].<ref name="NYTBoston" /> The leak was stopped on May 2.<ref name="NYTBoston" /> On May 4, the order was lifted.<ref name="google.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5geDUvZfc7dzGJd8oa6hV7msLnuEwD9FFTLQO1 |title=Boil water order is lifted for 2M in Boston area |accessdate=4 May 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100507041238/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5geDUvZfc7dzGJd8oa6hV7msLnuEwD9FFTLQO1 |archivedate=7 May 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> President [[Barack Obama]] signed an emergency disaster declaration offering federal help, authorizing the [[Department of Homeland Security]] and [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] to coordinate disaster relief efforts with Massachusetts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wbur.org/2010/05/03/obama-disaster-declaration |title=Obama Declares Mass. Emergency For Water Break |website=WBUR.org |date=2010-05-03 |accessdate=2016-08-20}}</ref>
MWRA executive director Frederick Laskey called the break "catastrophic"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebostonchannel.com/news/23337764/detail.html |title=MWRA Water Main Break Triggers State Of Emergency | WCVB Home – WCVB Home |publisher=Thebostonchannel.com |date=2010-05-02 |accessdate=2016-08-20}}</ref> and "everyone's worst nightmare in the water industry".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/yourtown/framingham/articles/2010/05/02/a_catastrophic_rupture_hits_regions_water_system/?p1=Well_MostPop_Emailed3 | newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] | title=A ‘catastrophic' rupture hits region's water system | first1=Michael | last1=Levenson | first2=Beth | last2=Daley | date=2010-05-02}}</ref>
==Chronology== At about 10 am on May 1, a collar connecting two sections of {{convert|10|ft|m|adj=mid|-wide}} pipe<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/05/03/mass_says_broken_pipe_could_be_fixed_within_days?mode=PF |title=Hope of fix within days |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100507145520/http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/05/03/mass_says_broken_pipe_could_be_fixed_within_days?mode=PF |archivedate=May 7, 2010 }} </ref> ruptured in [[Weston, Massachusetts]], disrupting the connection between the [[MetroWest Water Supply Tunnel]] and the City Tunnel.<ref name="NYTBoston" /><ref name="official">{{cite web|url=http://www.mwra.com/|title=MWRA homepage|accessdate=2010-05-02}}</ref>
With the water supply cut off, the emergency water supply reserve system from surrounding ponds was routed to the main water supply.
The rupture worsened as the afternoon progressed, eventually resulting in the loss of access to clean water from the [[Quabbin Reservoir|Quabbin]] and [[Wachusett Reservoir]]<nowiki/>s for approximately two million residents of 31 cities and towns, including Boston. At the height of the spill, approximately {{convert|8|e6USgal|m3}} of water entered the Charles River per hour.<ref name="NYTBoston" /> By evening, the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority had activated the backup water system, which was drawing water from the [[Chestnut Hill Reservoir]], and [[Spot Pond Reservoir]]. The Sudbury Aqueduct supplied additional water to the Chestnut Hill reservoir from the [[Sudbury Reservoir]] and the [[Framingham #3 reservoir]]. <ref name="official" /> Because water from these older surface reservoirs is not treated, the MWRA issued a [[boil order]] for the affected communities.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/05/02/a_catastrophic_rupture_hits_regions_water_system/|title=A ‘catastrophic’ rupture hits region’s water system | newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] | first1=Michael | last1=Levenson | first2=Beth | last2=Daley | date=2010-05-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mwra.state.ma.us/01news/2010/boilwaterorder1.htm |title=Mwra - Mwra Water Main Break Requires Water Ban, Boil Water Order |website=Mwra.state.ma.us |date= |accessdate=2016-08-20}}</ref>
The [[Massachusetts Water Resources Authority]] (MWRA) issued an emergency water notice for the Boston area. Governor [[Deval Patrick]] issued a [[state of emergency]] and a [[boil-water advisory]] for [[Boston]] and a dozen surrounding communities, affecting nearly 2 million people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2010/05/catastrophic_le.html |title='Boil-water' order issued for nearly 2 million in Mass. |newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] |first1=Martin |last1=Finucane |first2=Beth |last2=Daley |first3=John M. |last3=Guilfoil |first4=Sean |last4=Teehan |first5=Caitlin |last5=Castello |date=May 1, 2010 |accessdate=2 May 2010 <!--DASHBot--> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100503233105/http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2010/05/catastrophic_le.html |archivedate=3 May 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mwra.com/updates/leak.html |title=EMERGENCY WATER NOTICE | Starting May 1, 2010 - Updated Regularly |website=MWRA.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-20}}</ref>
Local agency officials used a variety of means to inform locals about the situation<ref name="NYTBoston">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/03/us/03boston.html |author=Derrick Henry|title=Ruptured Pipe Cuts Water in Boston|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 2, 2010|accessdate=2016-08-20}}</ref> including [[Everbridge]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.everbridge.com |title=Everbridge |publisher=Everbridge.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-20}}</ref> Boston's reverse 911 citizen alert system, highway alert signs, driving through affected neighborhoods with bullhorns, and other [[emergency management]] systems.<ref name="NYTBoston" /> As a result of the water boil order, many residents rushed to purchase [[bottled water]] at local stores. Many stores quickly sold out of water, and bottled water companies increased shipments at the request of the [[Massachusetts Emergency Management Agency]], maintaining availability at other stores.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2010/05/demand_for_bott.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505145458/http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2010/05/demand_for_bott.html |archivedate=2010-05-05 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.patriotledger.com/lifestyle/health_and_beauty/x1195009876/You-don-t-have-to-go-far-to-buy-water |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100509014506/http://www.patriotledger.com/lifestyle/health_and_beauty/x1195009876/You-don-t-have-to-go-far-to-buy-water |archivedate=2010-05-09 |df= }}</ref>
Local stores quickly sold out their supplies of bottled water, and the [[Massachusetts National Guard]] was dispatched to deliver additional bottled water.<ref name="NYTBoston" /> The state government also asked bottled-water suppliers to increase their deliveries to the area.<ref name="NYTBoston" /> Many cafes such as [[Starbucks]] and [[Dunkin' Donuts]] that depended on municipal water for coffee production were closed or forced to operate with limited functionality.
By May 2, workers had stopped the spill and begun repairs on the pipe and MWRA officials reported steady water pressure on the night of May 2.<ref name="NYTBoston" />
Experts and officials associated with the MWRA interviewed by reporters<ref name=a1>[http://www.necn.com/pages/landing?Boil-water-order-What-you-need-to-know=1&blockID=227079&feedID= ''Boil water order: What you need to know''], NECN Comcast Network, May 2, 2010.</ref><ref name=a2>[http://www.necn.com/05/02/10/Weston-water-main-break-not-worst-case/landing_newengland.html?blockID=227412&feedID=4206 ''Weston water main break not worst-case''], NECN Comcast Network, May 2, 2010.</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20130121132820/http://www.dailynewstribune.com/features/x826102585/Boil-water-order-remains-in-effect-but-progress-reported-on-water-main-break ''Boil-water order remains in effect''], ''but progress reported on water main break'', ''[[Daily News Tribune]]'', by Glen Johnson of the Associated Press, May 2, 2010.</ref> stated that the boil-water order was necessary because the backup reservoirs were untreated and unmonitored by bacterial cultures, which take a few days to run; similar situations had resulted in bacterial contamination bad enough to cause distressing [[Gastroenteritis|gastrointestinal symptoms]] in otherwise healthy adults.<ref name=a1 /><ref name=a2 />
On May 4, 2010, at 3 am, [[Massachusetts Water Resources Authority]] announced that Governor Patrick had lifted the water-boil order for all but one of affected communities, Saugus. In a press conference later that morning, Patrick stated that tests had since cleared the water in Saugus as well.<ref name="google.com"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6432V620100504?type=domesticNews|title=Boil-water ban lifted for Boston area | work=Reuters | first=Scott | last=Malone | date=May 4, 2010| accessdate= 7 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>
The test results indicated that the bacteria levels in the emergency supply were not atypical for a normal day. If this had been known earlier, the boil-water order would have been unnecessary.<ref> [http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/05/05/turns_out_water_was_ok_to_drink_after_all/ Tests confirm it — water was OK to drink all weekend] ''Boston.com'', May 5, 2010 </ref> No health effects for vulnerable classes, such as infants, pregnant women, and those with a compromised immune system, were reported in secondary sources during this event.
The engineering investigation<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amwa.net/galleries/default-file/MWRA%20Case%20Study%207-7-11.pdf |format=PDF |title=Multi-agency Response to a Major Water Pipe Break : A Massachusetts Case Study and Evaluation : Final Report |website=Amwa.net |accessdate=2016-08-20}}</ref> following the incident found that the break was caused by failure of the coupling bolts.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pantic|first=Zorica|title=MWRA MetroWest Water Supply Tunnel Shaft 5A Pipe Break—Pipe Failure Scenario Report|url=http://www.mwra.state.ma.us/01news/2011/052511-mwra-report-final.pdf|format=PDF|website=Mwra.state.ma.us|accessdate=4 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=LeBlanc|first=Steve|title=Report: Bolt Failure Caused 2010 Weston Water Main Break|url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2011/05/25/report-bolt-failure-caused-2010-weston-water-main-break/|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=4 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Daley|first=Beth|title=Wrong studs led to water main break, report says|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2011/05/26/wrong_studs_led_to_2010_water_main_break_report_says/|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|accessdate=4 June 2013|date=26 May 2011}}</ref> Inspection of recovered bolts and bolt fragments found that the bolts were poorly manufactured and sized incorrectly for the load.
==Affected communities== {{div col|colwidth=15em}} * [[Allston, Massachusetts|Allston]] * [[Arlington, Massachusetts|Arlington]] * [[Belmont, Massachusetts|Belmont]] * [[Boston]] * [[Brighton, Massachusetts|Brighton]] * [[Brookline, Massachusetts|Brookline]] * [[Canton, Massachusetts|Canton]] * [[Chelsea, Massachusetts|Chelsea]] * [[Everett, Massachusetts|Everett]] * [[Hanscom Air Force Base]] * [[Lexington, Massachusetts|Lexington]] * [[Lynnfield, Massachusetts|Lynnfield W.D.]] * [[Malden, Massachusetts|Malden]] * [[Marblehead, Massachusetts|Marblehead]] * [[Medford, Massachusetts|Medford]] * [[Melrose, Massachusetts|Melrose]] * [[Milton, Massachusetts|Milton]] * [[Nahant, Massachusetts|Nahant]] * [[Newton, Massachusetts|Newton]] * [[Norwood, Massachusetts|Norwood]] * [[Quincy, Massachusetts|Quincy]] * [[Reading, Massachusetts|Reading]] * [[Revere, Massachusetts|Revere]] * [[Saugus, Massachusetts|Saugus]] * [[Somerville, Massachusetts|Somerville]] * [[Stoneham, Massachusetts|Stoneham]] * [[Swampscott, Massachusetts|Swampscott]] * [[Waltham, Massachusetts|Waltham]] * [[Wakefield, Massachusetts|Wakefield]] * [[Watertown, Massachusetts|Watertown]] * [[Winchester, Massachusetts|Winchester]] * [[Winthrop, Massachusetts|Winthrop]] {{div col end}}

{{Infobox music festival| |dates=2009-2013; 2015-2016 |founded_by=Chris Flemmons of [[The Baptist Generals]] |genre={{hlist|[[Indie rock]]|[[Punk rock]]|[[Hip hop music|hip hop]]|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]|[[Pop music]]|[[Electronic music]]|[[Experimental music]]}} |image= 35 Denton Logo 2016.png |location=[[Denton, Texas]] |music_festival_name=35 Denton Music Festival |website=http://35denton.com }}
'''35 Denton''' (formerly '''NX35''' and '''35 Conferette''') is an annual 3-day music festival that takes place in the burgeoning arts corridor of downtown [[Denton, Texas]]. The festival is programmed each March the week prior to the music portion of [[SXSW]] in [[Austin, Texas]].
35 Denton is organized by a core staff of volunteers. The music festival has featured many nationally touring acts, such as [[The Pains of Being Pure At Heart]], [[Local Natives]], [[Portugal. The Man]], [[The Flaming Lips]], [[The Jesus and Mary Chain]], [[The Mountain Goats]], [[Bun B]], [[Devin the Dude]], [[Dr. Dog]], [[Big Boi]], [[Reggie Watts]], [[The Civil Wars]], [[Best Coast]], [[Danny Brown (rapper)|Danny Brown]], [[A Place to Bury Strangers]], and more. Likewise, it also has a roster of notable local acts, such as [[Neon Indian]], [[Midlake]], [[Sarah Jaffe]], [[Brave Combo]], [[Riverboat Gamblers]], [[Seryn]], and more.
==History== '''2005 – 2008: The Austin Years'''
During SXSW 2005, festival founder Chris Flemmons planted the seeds of 35 Denton in the soil of Big Red Sun, a floral design boutique in Austin. Thirteen Denton acts performed on a stage in the business's outdoor garden for an invite-only crowd of international journalists and industry types. The beer was free, the Tex-Mex was homemade, and the goal was uncomplicated: Show the world what Denton's all about. Flemmons called the event NX35: The Afternoon Party of the Other, Smaller, Music Town in Texas. In 2006, it took place at Club DeVille, and in 2007 and 2008, the party moved to Momo's. Some notable performers from the event's years in Austin include Centro-matic's [[Will Johnson (musician)|Will Johnson]], [[Midlake]], [[Sarah Jaffe]], and the [[Baptist Generals]].
'''2009 – Present: The Denton Years'''
In 2009, after four years in Austin, Flemmons and a small staff of volunteers brought the day party home and turned it into a multi-day festival. The goal of showcasing Denton's performers and people did not change, but the name did: NX35 Music Conferette, which opened with a keynote address led by [[American Splendor]] creator [[Harvey Pekar]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Waters |first=Erin |url=http://blogs.dallasobserver.com/dc9/2009/03/yesterday_at_nx35_a_conversation_about_jazz_with_harvey_pekar.php |title=Yesterday at NX35: A Conversation About Jazz with Harvey Pekar |newspaper=[[Dallas Observer]] |date=2009-03-15 |accessdate=2017-07-27}}</ref> Before the inaugural festival ended, more than 4000 people had watched over 120 acts play on the stages of Denton's numerous clubs and coffeeshops.
In 2010, more than 250 acts performed on and around Denton's downtown square – to an estimated audience of 20,000 people. The event began with keynote speaker [[Steve Albini]] and featured a now storied<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/news/north-by-unrest-chris-flemmons-wants-to-put-denton-music-on-the-map-with-nx35-if-it-doesnt-kill-him-first-6406254|title=North by Unrest: Chris Flemmons Wants To Put Denton Music on the Map With NX35-If it Doesn't Kill Him First|last=Rodrigue|first=Daniel|date=2010-03-11|access-date=2016-08-28}}</ref> free Saturday night performance by the [[Flaming Lips]] and Denton's own Midlake at the North Texas Fairgrounds. Other notable performers from this era include [[Neon Indian]], [[Centro-matic]], Health, [[The Black Angels (band)|The Black Angels]], [[Baptist Generals|The Baptist Generals]], [[Brave Combo]], [[Sarah Jaffe]], [[Monotonix]], [[The Riverboat Gamblers|Riverboat Gamblers]], and [[True Widow]].
In 2011, the festival changed its name to 35 Conferette. The name wasn't the only big change, as the fest expanded into the streets of downtown Denton with the addition of three outdoor stages, one of which was on the courthouse lawn. Performers included a growing roster of national talent like [[Big Boi]], [[Mavis Staples]], [[Dr. Dog]], [[Reggie Watts]], [[Japanther]], and [[Damien Jurado]]. In the months that followed, 35 Conferette was named Best Promotional Event of 2011 by the Texas Downtown Association. Festival founder Chris Flemmons handed the event's future to a new leadership staff led by Creative Director Kyle La Valley and Programming Director, Natalie Dávila. The festival's name changed to 35 Denton in July 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/the-scene/events/Denton-Music-Fest-Changes-Name-125085534.html|title=Denton Music Fest Changes Name|work=NBC 5 Dallas-Fort Worth|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en}}</ref>
In 2012, 35 Denton was headlined by [[The Jesus and Mary Chain]] – though they performed a few days later than anticipated. After visa issues prevented their Saturday night appearance, the band played the following Wednesday at the North Texas Fairgrounds, with [[Ty Segall]] as an opening act. Other notable 2012 acts included [[Built to Spill]], [[Bun B]], [[The Raincoats]], OM, [[Best Coast]], [[Oh Sees|Thee Oh Sees]], and [[Dum Dum Girls]].[[File:Flaming Lips at NX35 2010.jpg|thumb|250px|[[The Flaming Lips]] performing a free show during NX35 2010]]In 2013, 35 Denton featured performances by [[Solange Knowles|Solange]], Sleep, [[Roky Erickson]], [[Com Truise]], [[Silver Apples]], [[Killer Mike]], [[Thee Oh Sees]], [[Akron/Family]], [[Man Man]], [[Mikal Cronin]], [[Mac DeMarco]], [[Beach Fossils]], [[Reigning Sound]], [[Marnie Stern]], [[Soul Clap]], and the live Texas debut of [[Thurston Moore]]'s side-project [[Chelsea Light Moving]].
After 2013, La Valley and Dávila left the festival leadership and the organization's primary investors withdrew funding<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/entertainment/the-scene/35-Denton-at-Risk-as-Staff--Financial-Backer-Part-Ways-214221121.html|title=35 Denton at Risk as Staff and Financial Backer Part Ways|work=NBC 5 Dallas-Fort Worth|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en}}</ref>. The festival did not take place in 2014, opting instead to take a year off to reorganize and locate new investors. During this time, a new Denton music festival in [http://oaktopiafest.com Oaktopia] was formed to run opposite 35 Denton in the fall of each year.
In 2015, 35 Denton returned under the theme "Back To The Music", and featured performances by the 1970s [[The Zombies]], [[Jimmie Dale Gilmore]], [[Cymbals Eat Guitars]], [[Chastity Belt (band)]], [[Lowell (musician)]], S U R V I V E, and the reunion performance of [[Ten Hands (band)]] led by local musician Paul Slavens.
In 2016, was headlined by the soul artist [[Charles Bradley (singer)]] and his Extraordinaires, hip-hop throwback [[Biz Markie]], and [[Eliot Sumner]], the child of English rock musician [[Sting (musician)]]. Other notable performances were by [[Electric Six]], [[Fat Tony (rapper)]], [[Class Actress]], [[Tacocat]], [[Sheer Mag]], Alesia Lani and the [[Mydolls]].
The 2017 event was canceled without firm plans to revive the festival.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.guidelive.com/music/2017/02/06/official-35-denton-music-festival-canceled|title=It's official: 35 Denton music festival is not happening this year|date=2017-02-06|work=GuideLive|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en}}</ref>
== Evolution of a brand == <gallery mode="packed-hover" heights="200"> File:Nx35 2009.jpg|NX35 Music Conferette 2009 Banner with Logo File:NX35 2009.jpg|NX35 Music Conferette 2010 Banner with Logo File:35 Conferette Logo 2011.png|35 Conferette 2011 Logo File:35 Denton Logo 2012.jpg|35 Denton Music Festival 2012 Logo File:35 Denton 2013.jpg|35 Denton Music Festival 2013 Logo File:35 Denton Logo 2016.png|35 Denton Music Festival 2016 Logo </gallery>A unique aspect of the festival is its evolving name and image; each change coming from a different impetus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dmagazine.com/arts-entertainment/2011/07/the-road-to-35-the-meaning-and-reasons-behind-a-festivals-various-name-changes/|title=The Road to 35: The Meaning and Reasons Behind A Festival’s Various Name-Changes – D Magazine|website=www.dmagazine.com|access-date=2016-08-28}}</ref>

Materials of note within the museum collection include 500 sealed eight tracks by [[The Rutles]] (with the original shipping cartons), a three-pack eight track box set of recordings by [[The Beatles]], and thirty sealed eight tracks by [[Elvis Presley]] (in their original [[RCA Records]] shipping carton). In conjunction with the exhibition opening, Burnett curates a special exhibition entitled "Metal Machine Music: 35 Years" focused on the thirty-fifth anniversary of the release of [[Lou Reed]]'s infamous 1975 double album, featuring eight tracks of many of Reed's legendary projects and associates, including rare sealed tapes from [[The Velvet Underground]], [[Nico]], and more.}} |}

===The Hot Wet Mess===
In May 2012, 35 Denton announced a one-day end of summer party to take place on September 1, 2012 entitled 'The Hot Wet Mess.' The festival's first venture into event production outside the 35 Denton festival took place at the North Texas Fairgrounds and featured [[Black Lips]], [[No Age]], [[Reggie Watts]], [[Big Freedia]], [[Unknown Mortal Orchestra]] as well as local acts [[Fergus & Geronimo]], DJ Sober and RTB2. The event was sponsored by [[Vitamin Water]] and [[Corona Light]], and consisted of attractions such as a water slide to overlook the stage.

{{distinguish|Abattoir}} '''Abertoir''' is an annual horror and [[horror films|horror film]] festival held in the [[Aberystwyth]] [[Aberystwyth Arts Centre|Arts Centre]] in [[Ceredigion]], [[Wales]] in November. The festival began as a three-day event and has grown since to a six-day programme of films and events. Abertoir is Wales' only dedicated horror film festival and is a member of the [[European Fantastic Film Festivals Federation]]. As well as screening new big-budget horror films, classics and independent films form a large and important part of the festival line-up. Each year a short film competition is held, which showcases horror and fantasy short films from around the world. In addition to film screenings, the festival regularly features presentations, concerts, theatre shows, masterclasses, a pub quiz and off-site screenings in its line up.
==Notable guests of honour==
* [[Lloyd Kaufman]] (2007) * [[Mark Gatiss]] (2008) * [[Doug Bradley]] (2008 and 2009) * [[Herschell Gordon Lewis]] (2009) * [[Robin Hardy (film director)|Robin Hardy]] (2006 and 2010) * [[Victoria Price]] (daughter of [[Vincent Price]]) (2011 and 2015) * [[Catriona MacColl]] (2012) * [[Richard Johnson (actor)|Richard Johnson]] (2013) * [[Fabio Frizzi]] (2013, 2015 & 2016) * [[Luigi Cozzi]] (2014 & 2016) * [[Ian McCulloch (actor)|Ian McCulloch]] (2014) * Dario Russo and David Ashby (creators of [[Danger 5]]) (2015) * [[Lynn Lowry]] (2016) * [[Sergio Martino]] (2017) * [[Lamberto Bava]] (2017) * [[Brian O'Malley (director)|Brian O'Malley]] (2017)

{{unreferenced|date=May 2007}} The '''Animex International Festival of Animation and Computer Games''' takes place every year in [[Middlesbrough]] in the [[North East England|North East]] of [[England]]. The festival has its roots firmly planted in the creative side of the animation and computer games industries and acts to provide animators, directors, students, artists, designers, writers and educators with a forum in which they can share their knowledge and skills and promote the art of animation and computer games development.
Animex began as a two-day series of lectures by animators and industry professionals at the [[University of Teesside]] in February 2000, and has rapidly grown to a week-long festival incorporating the two-day event that began it all, '''Animex Talk'''. '''Animex Game''' expanded on this idea in 2004, by creating another two days of presentations, this time by games professionals. 2013 sees the birth of a new comics day, the first event hosted by Jim Zubkavich of [[Udon Entertainment]]
The main venue for the festival is The University of Teesside, with other events taking place at [[Cineworld]] Cinema and other venues throughout Middlesbrough and the rest of the north east.
The festival also runs an exhibition of animation and games art, an international student awards scheme, screenings, workshops and Animexperience, a programme of school and community events giving people the chance to try their hand at animation and meet industry luminaries.
Guest speakers in the past have included such industry professionals as [[Pixar]] animator Mark Walsh, [[Bob the Builder]] designer [[Curtis Jobling]], Phil Tippett, Nancy Cartwright, the voice of Bart Simpson, owner of Ritual Entertainment Richard [[Levelord]] Gray, [[Valve]], [[Epic Games|Epic]], [[Naughty Dog]], [[Blitz Games]], [[Ernest W. Adams]], [[Chris Crawford (game designer)|Chris Crawford]], Professor Stuart Sumida and representatives from almost every major games and animation studio around the world.
Animex was in part the inspiration for the [[Red Stick International Animation Festival]] in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]], [[Louisiana]].
Animex is run by animation and computer games lecturers within the [[University of Teesside]].
*Festival Director - Gabrielle Kent *Animex Talk and Screen - Chris Wyatt *Animex Exhibition - Stephen Murray *Festival Founder - Chris Williams
==External links== * [http://www.animex.net/ Animex official site] * [http://www.tees.ac.uk/ University of Teesside]

{{Other people|Bob Parker|Bob Parker (disambiguation)}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=June 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Sir Bob Parker |honorific-suffix = {{post-nominals|country=NZL|KNZM|size=100%}} |image = Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker.jpg |alt = |caption = Bob Parker in 2011 |order = 45th |office = Mayor of Christchurch |term_start = October 2007 |term_end = October 2013 |predecessor = [[Garry Moore (mayor)|Garry Moore]] |successor = [[Lianne Dalziel]] |birth_name = Robert John Parker |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1953|1|13|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Christchurch]], New Zealand |death_date = |death_place = |restingplace = |restingplacecoordinates = |nationality = New Zealand |party = Independent |spouse = (2nd marriage) Joanna Parker-Nicholls |relations = |children = |residence = [[Christchurch Central City]] |alma_mater = |occupation = |profession = |cabinet = |committees = |portfolio = |religion = |signature = |signature_alt= |website = |footnotes = }}
'''Sir Robert John Parker''' {{post-nominals|country=NZL|KNZM}} (born 13 January 1953) is a former New Zealand broadcaster and politician. He served as [[Mayor of Christchurch]] from 2007 to 2013.
==Early years== Parker grew up in the [[Christchurch]] suburbs of [[Heathcote Valley]] and [[Somerfield, New Zealand|Somerfield]]. He attended [[Christchurch South Intermediate]] and [[Cashmere High School]]. He studied an intermediate year in [[zoology]] at the [[University of Canterbury]] before undertaking casual work.<ref name="bio">{{cite web |url=http://ccc.govt.nz/thecouncil/mayor/biography.aspx |title=Mayor Bob Parker – biography |publisher=Christchurch City Council |accessdate=27 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111222045858/http://www.ccc.govt.nz/thecouncil/mayor/biography.aspx |archivedate=22 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Broadcasting career== Parker got his first job on radio, in Nelson. His broadcasting career then took him to Christchurch, Wellington and then Auckland.<ref name="bio" /> He was the associate producer and original host (1984–1996) of the New Zealand version of the ''[[This Is Your Life (New Zealand TV series)|This is Your Life]]'' series after he purchased the New Zealand television rights for the show from Ralph Edwards Productions in California. He returned to Christchurch in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nztourismconference.co.nz/Programme---Highlights/Speakers-Biographies.asp |title=Speakers Biographies – Bob Parker |date=1 August 2008 |publisher=Tourism Industry Conference New Zealand |accessdate=27 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091105015652/http://www.nztourismconference.co.nz/Programme---Highlights/Speakers-Biographies.asp |archivedate=5 November 2009 }}</ref>
==Local body politics== Parker's local government career spanned more than two decades. He first became politically active when he filled a councillor vacancy on the [[Banks Peninsula District]] Council in 1994.<ref name="Press bio">{{cite news |title=Twenty years serving the community |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=19 June 2013 |page=A5}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Television star new mayor of Banks Peninsula|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=222678|accessdate=25 April 2015|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|agency=[[The Star (Christchurch)|The Star]]|date=13 October 2001}}</ref> Having lived in [[Akaroa]] for several years, he served as mayor of [[Banks Peninsula]] District for two terms (2001–2006). He favoured amalgamation of the district with Christchurch City and led a high profile and controversial campaign leading to a poll in 2005. Amalgamation with the City was supported by 65% of the Peninsula's voters<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bobparker.co.nz/index.html |title=bobparker.co.nz |accessdate=2009-07-12 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040803041710/http://www.bobparker.co.nz/index.html |archivedate=3 August 2004 |df=dmy }}.</ref> Amalgamation took place on 3 March 2006, at which Parker, after winning a by-election, became a Christchurch city councillor, and the sole Banks Peninsula representative on the council.<ref name="Press bio"/>
In 2006 Parker was elected as the independent chair of the Greater Christchurch Urban Development Strategy. This saw the bringing together of four local councils—Christchurch, Selwyn, Waimakariri and the Canterbury Regional Council—for a major planning undertaking based on creating a sustainable growth plan for the greater Christchurch area. The Strategy was adopted in 2007 by all of the member councils and is today the basis for all spatial planning in the greater Christchurch area.
In October 2007, Parker successfully stood in the [[New Zealand local elections, 2007|local government elections]] for the [[Christchurch mayoral election, 2007|Christchurch mayoralty]], after the retirement of [[Garry Moore (mayor)|Garry Moore]].<ref name="NZ_Herald_10469695">{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/story.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=10469695 |title=New faces aplenty in local government shake-ups |author=Gay, Edward |date=13 October 2007 |newspaper=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref> He received 47,033 votes, with [[Megan Woods]] (32,821) and [[Jo Giles]] (14,454) in the election contested by ten candidates.<ref>{{cite web |title=Christchurch City Mayor |url=http://www.elections2010.co.nz/2007/elections/christchurch-city-mayor |publisher=Local Elections 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827073353/http://www.elections2010.co.nz/2007/elections/christchurch-city-mayor# |archive-date=27 August 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Parker announced in 2009 that he would seek re-election at the [[Christchurch mayoral election, 2010|2010 Christchurch mayoral election]].<ref name="Gordon candidacy">{{cite news |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/3597603/Gordon-announces-mayoral-candidacy |title=Gordon to enter race |last=Conway |first=Glenn |date=20 April 2010 |publisher=The Press |page=A2 |accessdate=20 April 2010 |location=Christchurch}}</ref>
Despite being the incumbent, he initially polled behind his major challenger<ref name="UMR June opinion poll">{{Cite web |title=Mayoralty SurveyChristchurch City Council |url=http://www.umr.co.nz/Media/Christchurch_MayoralElectionResearch_Jun10.pdf |publisher=UMR Research |accessdate=20 July 2010 |location=Wellington |format=PDF |date=June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724195105/http://www.umr.co.nz/Media/Christchurch_MayoralElectionResearch_Jun10.pdf |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="umr_1">{{Cite web |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO1006/S00145.htm |title=Anderton Leading Parker In Race|publisher=UMR Research Ltd |date=14 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="Stuff.co.nz_4070928">{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/4070928/ |title=Anderton leads in mayoral race |author=Conway, Glenn |date=28 August 2010 |work=[[The Press]] |accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref> until the large [[2010 Canterbury earthquake]]<ref>[http://www.geonet.org.nz/earthquake/quakes/3366146g.html Christchurch 7.1magnitude – 4.35am Sat 4th Sept 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100905223314/http://www.geonet.org.nz/earthquake/quakes/3366146g.html |date=5 September 2010 }}, Geonet, Christchurch Earthquake Reference</ref> on 4 September 2010. His high-profile handling of the civil emergency was widely praised,<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_4105641">{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/4105641/ |title=Parker's 20-hour days for 'a personal thing' |author=Conway, Glenn |date=8 September 2010 |work=[[The Press]] |accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref> and polls taken later showed him taking the lead.<ref name="NZ_Herald_10671734">{{cite web |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10671734 |title=Christchurch mayor's stock rises post-quake |date=6 September 2010 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref> It was announced on 9 October that Parker had been re-elected for a second term with 68,245 of the votes to [[Jim Anderton]]'s 51,566 based on 98% of the votes counted.<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_4215351">{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/4215351/Bob-Parker-re-elected-Christchurch-Mayor |title=Bob Parker re-elected Christchurch Mayor |author=Conway, Glenn |date=9 October 2010 |work=[[The Press]] |accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref>
===2010 earthquake=== [[File:Band Together Concert For Canterbury.jpg|thumb|Parker performing with [[The Bats (New Zealand band)|The Bats]] at the Band Together Concert For Canterbury in October 2010]] Parker was the incumbent mayor at the time of the [[2010 Canterbury earthquake|September 2010 Canterbury earthquake]]. During the days following the quake, he worked with [[Civil Defence]], the police and the New Zealand Army to get the city back up and running. In October 2010, Christchurch band [[The Bats (New Zealand band)|The Bats]] and many others played at a free earthquake relief concert in [[Hagley Park, Christchurch|Hagley Park]] in front of about 140,000 people. Parker joined The Bats for the performance and played guitar.<ref>{{cite news |title=Rocking for right reasons |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/4269120/Rocking-for-right-reasons |accessdate=21 October 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=25 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Bob and The Bats on show |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/4217870/Bob-and-The-Bats-on-show |accessdate=21 October 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=11 October 2010}}</ref>
Before the earthquake, some polls had Parker trailing Anderton but his high profile since 4 September and cool handling of the earthquake's aftermath won him widespread praise and the support of voters who overwhelmingly backed him to run the city for a second term.<ref name="Parker re-elected">{{cite news |last=Conway |first=Glenn |title=Bob Parker re-elected Christchurch Mayor |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/local-elections-2010/4215351/Bob-Parker-re-elected-Christchurch-Mayor |accessdate=22 December 2011 |newspaper=stuff.co.nz |date=9 October 2010}}</ref>
===2011 earthquake=== [[File:Mayor bob Parker speaks to ships' companies in Lyttelton.jpg|thumb|Mayor Parker speaks to ships' companies in the port town [[Lyttelton, New Zealand|Lyttelton]]]] Parker was the media face of the recovery efforts in the aftermath of the February [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]], working with the police and the army and rescue squads, as well as answering the media's questions.
On 18 March 2011, Parker addressed the national Christchurch memorial service at [[Hagley Park (New Zealand)|Hagley Park]] of Christchurch in the presence of [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]], Prime Minister [[John Key]], Dame [[Malvina Major]], [[Hayley Westenra]], [[ChristChurch Cathedral, Christchurch|ChristChurch Cathedral]] Choir, dignitaries, international rescue teams and tens of thousands of [[New Zealanders]].<ref name="TVNZ_4071980">{{cite web |url= http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/christchurch-quake-memorial-service-happened-4071417/video?vid=4071980 |title=Christchurch quake memorial service: As it happened |date=18 March 2011 |work=[[Television New Zealand]] |accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref>
After the February earthquake the New Zealand Government brought in a special act of Parliament, [[The Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Act]], which essentially passed ultimate responsibility for the [[rebuilding of post-quake Christchurch]] to the Government. The Council was given the task of preparing a new plan to rebuild the central business district of the city. The project, chaired by Parker, was titled "share an idea". It won international acclaim for the Council, including the international "Co Creation" award - the first time this award had been granted outside of Europe.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.stoppress.co.nz/blog/2011/11/strategys-share-an-idea-gets-international-co-creation-plaudits | title=Strategy's Share an Idea gets international co-creation plaudits | work=StopPress | date=28 November 2011 | accessdate=17 September 2014 | author=StopPress Team}}</ref>
Outrage was expressed at the Council, after Christchurch City Council CEO [[Tony Marryatt]] was given a near $70,000 pay rise in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Christchurch protest over city chief's pay rise |url= http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/christchurch-protest-over-city-chief-s-pay-rise-4666796 |accessdate=22 December 2011 |newspaper=TVNZ |date=22 December 2011}}</ref> A protest was held at the City Council Building on 1 February 2012. Approximately 4000 citizens turned up to protest the decision of the City Council, and to call for a mid-term election.<ref name="CCC protest">{{cite news |last=Sachdeva |first=Sam |title=Protesters threaten rates revolt in Christchurch |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/6351630/Protesters-threaten-rates-revolt-in-Christchurch |accessdate=4 February 2012 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=2 February 2012}}</ref>
In April 2013 when the government announced the cost of the rebuild was going to be as much as $40 billion, Parker said it was "no surprise", and welcomed the extra investment as being "good for [[Gross domestic product|GDP]]".<ref>{{cite news| first = Dan |last = Satherley | url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Rebuild-cost-jump-no-surprise---Parker/tabid/423/articleID/295852/Default.aspx|work=[[3 News NZ]] |title= Rebuild cost jump 'no surprise' - Parker| date=29 April 2013 |accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Bob's Mob cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Residential protest against Parker and CEO [[Tony Marryatt]]]] In mid-June 2013, Minister for Earthquake Recovery [[Gerry Brownlee]] revealed in a press conference that [[International Accreditation New Zealand]] (IANZ) had written to [[Christchurch City Council]] threatening to revoke its accreditation for issuing building consents. This caught Parker by surprise, as he knew nothing of this threat, and he criticised Brownlee for not communicating with him before the press conference; Parker famously labelled Brownlee's practice a "media missile".<ref>{{cite news |title=Ultimatum in consent crisis looms |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/8794459/Ultimatum-in-consent-crisis-looms |accessdate=5 July 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=14 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Cairns |first=Lois |title=Council's 'arranged marriage' on the rocks |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/opinion/8794426/Councils-arranged-marriage-on-the-rocks |accessdate=5 July 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] | date=14 June 2013}}</ref> Brownlee and Parker had at times a strained relationship, with the government taking an increasing amount of control in local decision making.<ref>{{cite news |title=Race to decide who's the boss |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/8828396/Race-to-decide-whos-the-boss |accessdate=5 July 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=22 June 2013}}</ref>
In July 2013, Parker announced on ''[[Campbell Live]]'' he would not be running for re-election in the [[Christchurch mayoral election, 2013|2013 Christchurch mayoral elections]], citing exhaustion and not having the required energy for a third term as mayor. He stated that although staff had assured him they would satisfy the requirements of the consenting process the accreditation had been withdrawn;<ref name="accreditation lost">{{cite news |last1=O'Callaghan |first1=Jody |last2=Young |first2=Rachel |last3=Cairns |first3=Lois |title=Govt to move on consent debacle <!-- note that the printed version is somewhat different from the online version; the heading is from the printed version -->|url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/8865188/Consents-Marryatt-must-front |accessdate=5 July 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=2 July 2013 |location=Christchurch |pages=A1-A2}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Christchurch City Council CEO takes leave |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/8873496/Christchurch-City-Council-CEO-takes-leave |accessdate=5 July 2013 |newspaper=[[Fairfax New Zealand]] |date=3 July 2013}}</ref> as this had happened on "his watch" as Mayor he felt he should take responsibility for the loss.<ref name=quits>{{cite news |last=O'Callaghan |first=Jody |title=Embattled Mayor Parker quits<!-- The online version of this article has the additional word "Embattled" in the title --> |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/local-elections-2013/8885574/Embattled-Mayor-Parker-quits |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130705203953/http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/local-elections-2013/8885574/Embattled-Mayor-Parker-quits |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 July 2013 |accessdate=6 July 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=6 July 2013 |page=A1 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Conway |first=Glenn |title='This happened on my watch' - Parker |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/local-elections-2013/8887205/This-happened-on-my-watch-Parker |accessdate=6 July 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=6 July 2013}}</ref>
In July 2013 an editorial in ''[[The Press]]'' noted that a tribute paid to Parker by the Prime Minister of New Zealand [[John Key]] was "well deserved".<ref>http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/opinion/editorials/8966098/Editorial-Parker-tribute-well-deserved</ref> The Prime Minister in a speech to the [[Local Government New Zealand]] organisation in 2013 stated that Parker's "commitment to the city during its darkest hours will be his legacy".<ref name="LGNZ">{{cite web| url=https://www.national.org.nz/news/news/media-releases/detail/2013/07/22/address-to-2013-local-government-new-zealand-conference | title=Address to 2013 Local Government New Zealand Conference | date=23 July 2013 | accessdate=17 September 2014 | author=Rt Hon John Key|publisher=[[New Zealand National Party]]}}</ref>
In the [[2014 New Year Honours (New Zealand)|2014 New Year Honours]], Parker was appointed a [[New Zealand Order of Merit|Knight Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit]] for services to local-body affairs and the community.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.dpmc.govt.nz/publications/new-year-honours-list-2014 | title=New Year honours list 2014|date=31 December 2013 | publisher=Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet | accessdate=11 January 2018}}</ref> An editorial in ''The Press'' stated that Parker had "fronted the media coverage of the two disasters and the ensuing civil emergencies to local and international media. His calm leadership throughout the emergency periods were noted for providing reassurance and hope to the people of Christchurch."<ref>http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/opinion/editorials/9564989/Editorial-Controversial-but-deserved</ref>
== Awards and recognition== * Knight Companion New Zealand Order of Merit (2014) * Member N.Z. Institute of Directors * Paul Harris Fellow award 2013 - The Rotary International Foundation * Pegasus Health 2013 Chairmans award for Outstanding Leadership * Minister of Civil Defence Award, 2012 * Public Relations Institute N Z Communicator of the Year 2012 * New Zealander of the Year "Local Hero" award, 2012 * Justice of the Peace (2000)
==Personal life== Parker has three sons from his first marriage, plus three grandchildren. His second marriage is to Joanna Nicholls-Parker.<ref name="bio" />

'''Chalica''' is a holiday celebrated by [[Unitarian Universalists]]. It traditionally begins on the first Monday in December and lasts seven days,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uuworld.org/articles/chalica-gains-adherents |title=Chalica, new weeklong UU holiday, slowly gains adherents |last1=Skinner |first1=Donald E. |last2= |first2= |date=7 December 2009 |website= |publisher= |access-date=5 August 2015 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uua.org/worship/holidays/chalica |title=Celebrating Chalica |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=uua.org |publisher=[[Unitarian Universalist Association]] |access-date=5 August 2015 |quote=}}</ref> though a [[#Variations|seven-week variant]] beginning in January is also observed.<ref name="7-week-variant">{{cite web|title=Chalica – A time of reflection and renewal|url=http://uubgky.org/spirit/our-traditions/chalica/|website=UUBGKY.org|publisher=Unitarian Universalist Church of Bowling Green}}</ref> On each of the seven nights (or weeks), a different [[Unitarian Universalism#Seven Principles and Purposes|principle of Unitarian Universalism]] is honored.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chalica.blogspot.com/p/history-of-chalica.html |title=Chalica.info: History |last1=Klink-Zeitz |first1=Kathy |last2= |first2= |date= |website=chalica.blogspot.com |publisher= |access-date=5 August 2015 |quote=}}</ref> On each day, a [[chalice]] is ignited, the day's principle is read, and ways of honoring the principle are enacted, such as volunteering or donating to a social justice cause.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.uuworld.org/parenting/2010/12/06/celebrating-the-winter-holidays/ |title=Celebrating the winter holidays |last1=Richards |first1=Michelle |last2= |first2= |date=6 December 2010 |website= |publisher= |access-date=5 August 2015 |quote= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101210033416/http://blogs.uuworld.org/parenting/2010/12/06/celebrating-the-winter-holidays/ |archive-date=2010-12-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brisbaneuu.org.au/UU_Traditions.html |title=Some UU Traditions |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=brisbaneuu.org.au |publisher=Brisbane Unitarian Universalist Fellowship Home Page |access-date=5 August 2015 |quote=}}</ref> There is no rule for how the chalice or display should look, but there are traditionally seven candles around the chalice, one for each principle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/amanda-gregory/another-winter-holiday_b_4372209.html |title=Another Winter Holiday!? |author=Amanda Gregory |publisher=The Huffington Post |date=December 2, 2013 |accessdate=December 6, 2016}}</ref> Activities on each day vary, and may include discussions, group activities, and songs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.firstuu.com/images/downloads/Chalica.pdf |title=My Chalica Book: A Beginner's Guide |edition=Second |author=Meredith Plummer |date=November 20, 2013 |orig-year=2012 |publisher=First Unitarian Church of Cincinnati |accessdate=December 6, 2016}}</ref>
== History == Chalica was created as a holiday in 2005 by Daylene Marshall.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wuuc.org/2014/12/chalica/ |title=Chalica |last1=Van Leer |first1=Lois E. |last2= |first2= |date=11 December 2014 |website=wuuc.org |publisher=Woodville Unitarian Universalist Church |access-date=5 August 2015 |quote=}}</ref> While it has gained followers since, it is not a widely celebrated holiday.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uuworld.org/articles/chalica-gains-adherents |title=Chalica, new weeklong UU holiday, slowly gains adherents |author=Donald E. Skinner |date=December 7, 2009 |accessdate=December 6, 2016}}</ref>
== Variations == To solve the problem of having only a single week in which to cram seven [[wiktionary:nonnominal|nonnominal]] deeds for the [[Unitarian_Universalism#Seven_Principles_and_Purposes|seven Unitarian Universalist principles]], the Unitarian Universalist Church of Bowling Green in Kentucky extends Chalica into a seven-week observance. Further, Chalica at the Unitarian Universalist Church of Bowling Green starts on the first Sunday in January as an extension of the [[New Year's resolution]] concept.<ref name="7-week-variant"></ref>
