page.title: Predictions of the dissolution of the Soviet Union

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
There were people and organizations who '''predicted that the USSR would fall''' before the eventual [[dissolution of the Soviet Union|dissolution of the USSR]] in 1991.Historians point to dissolution beginning with the [[Polish Round Table Agreement]] in 1989 Authors often credited with having predicted the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]] include [[Andrei Amalrik]] in ''[[Andrei Amalrik#Will the Soviet Union Survive Until 1984?|Will the Soviet Union Survive Until 1984?]]'' (1970), [[France|French]] academic [[Emmanuel Todd]] in ''[[Emmanuel Todd#Prediction of the collapse of the USSR|La chute finale: Essais sur la décomposition de la sphère Soviétique]] (The Final Fall: An essay on the decomposition of the Soviet sphere)'' (1976), economist [[Ravi Batra]] in his 1978 book ''[[The Downfall of Capitalism and Communism]]'' and French historian [[Hélène Carrère d'Encausse]]. {{cite book | author = [[Flora Lewis]] | year =1987 | title = Europe: A Tapestry of Nations | publisher =Simon and Schuster | location =USA | isbn =0-671-44018-7 | page = 364 }} Additionally, [[Walter Laqueur]] notes that "Various articles that appeared in professional journals such as ''[[Problems of Communism (journal)|Problems of Communism]]'' and ''Survey'' dealt with the decay and the possible downfall of the Soviet regime."{{cite book | last =Laqueur | first =Walter | authorlink = Walter Laqueur | year =1996 | title =The Dream that Failed : Reflections on the Soviet Union | publisher =Oxford University Press | location =USA | pages = 187–191 | isbn =0-19-510282-7 }} Some [[American conservatism|US conservatives]]{{cite web|last=Knopf |first=Jeffrey W. |authorlink= |date=August 2004 |url=http://www.ccc.nps.navy.mil/si/2004/aug/knopfAUG04.asp |title=Did Reagan Win the Cold War? |work=Strategic Insights, Volume III, Issue 8 |publisher=Center for Contemporary Conflict at the Naval Postgraduate School |accessdate=2006-04-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301021952/http://www.ccc.nps.navy.mil/si/2004/aug/knopfAUG04.asp |archivedate=March 1, 2009 }}{{cite web | last = Owens | first = Mackubin Thomas | authorlink = | date = June 5, 2004 | url = http://www.nationalreview.com/owens/owens200406051832.asp | title = The Reagan of History: Reflections on the death of Ronald Reagan. | work = | publisher = National Review Online | accessdate = April 20, 2006 }} view [[Ronald Reagan]]'s [[Strategic Defense Initiative]] as not only predicting but causing the dissolution of the USSR. Whether any particular prediction was ''correct'' is still a matter of debate, since they give different reasons and different time frames for the Soviet collapse. ==Conventional wisdom discounting a collapse== ===U.S. analysts=== Predictions of the Soviet Union's impending demise were discounted by many [[Western world|Western]] academic specialists,{{cite news | first=Ian | last=Cummins | author= | url= | title=The Great MeltDown | work= | publisher=The Australian | pages= | page= | date=23 December 1995 | accessdate=}} and had little impact on mainstream [[Kremlinology|Sovietology]].{{cite news | first=Jonas | last=Bernstein | author= | url= | title=Postmortem is also warning on optimism over Russia | work= | publisher=The Washington Times | pages= | page=B8 | date=22 January 1995 | accessdate=}}  (Review of ''The Dream That Failed: Reflections on the Soviet Union'') For example, Amalrik's book "was welcomed as a piece of brilliant literature in the West" but "virtually no one tended to take it at face value as a piece of political prediction." Up to about 1980, the strength of the Soviet Union was widely overrated by critics and [[Historiography of the Cold War#Revisionism|revisionists]] alike. In 1983, [[Princeton University]] professor [[Stephen F. Cohen|Stephen Cohen]] described the [[Politics of the Soviet Union|Soviet system]] as remarkably stable. The [[Central Intelligence Agency]] also badly over-estimated the internal stability of the Soviet Union, and did not anticipate the speed of its collapse. Former DCI Stansfield Turner in 1991 wrote in the US Journal ''Foreign Affairs'', "We should not gloss over the enormity of this failure to forecast the magnitude of the Soviet crisis . . . Yet I never heard a suggestion from the CIA, or the intelligence arms of the departments of Defense or State, that numerous Soviets recognized a growing, systemic economic problem."Cited on page 108 of {{cite book |last1=Jones |first1=Milo L. and |last2=Silberzahn |first2=Philippe|year=2013 |title=Constructing Cassandra, Reframing Intelligence Failure at the CIA, 1947-2001|publisher=Stanford University Press |isbn=978-0804793360}} In a symposium launched to review [[Michel Garder]]'s French book: ''L'Agonie du Regime en Russie Sovietique'' (''The Death Struggle of the Regime in Soviet Russia''), which also predicted the collapse of the USSR, [[Yale University|Yale]] Professor Frederick C. Barghoorn dismissed Garder's book as "the latest in a long line of apocalyptic predictions of the collapse of communism." He warns that "great revolutions are most infrequent and that successful [[political system]]s are tenacious and adaptive." In addition, the reviewer of the book, Michael Tatu, disapproved of the "apocalyptic character" of such a forecast and is almost apologetic for treating it seriously.{{cite book |last=Lyons |first=Eugene |authorlink= |year=1967 |title=Workers' Paradise Lost |url=http://www.ca-politicaltransitions.com/Classes/PoliticalIdeas/Socialism/WorkersParadiseIndex.html |publisher=Paperback Library |location=New York |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061018210213/http://www.ca-politicaltransitions.com/Classes/PoliticalIdeas/Socialism/WorkersParadiseIndex.html |archivedate=2006-10-18 |df= }} ; ==Predictions of dissolution or collapse== Analysts, organizations and politicians who predicted that the Soviet Union would one day cease to exist included: ===Ludwig von Mises=== The Austrian economist [[Ludwig von Mises]] argued in his 1921 book ''[[Socialism: An Economic and Sociological Analysis]]'' that the Soviet system was unsustainable and would eventually collapse. This book was published months before Lenin implemented the [[New Economic Policy]] reintroducing partial [[private property]] in agriculture. Mises' analysis was based on the [[economic calculation problem]], a critique of central planning first outlined in 1920 journal articles. His argument was that the Soviet Union would find itself increasingly unable to set correct prices for the goods and services it produced:
We may admit that in its initial period a socialist regime could to some extent rely on the preceding age of capitalism [for the purpose of determining prices]. But what is to be done later, as conditions change more and more? Of what use could the prices of 1900 be for the director in 1949? And what use can the director in 1989 derive from knowledge of the prices of 1949?
===Leon Trotsky=== One of the founders of the USSR, later expelled by [[Joseph Stalin]], [[Leon Trotsky]] devoted much of his time in exile to the question of the Soviet Union's future. In time, he came to believe that a new revolution was necessary to depose the [[nomenklatura]] and reinstate [[dictatorship of the proletariat|working class rule]] as the first step to [[socialism]]. In 1936 he made the following prediction: {{quote|In order better to understand the character of the present Soviet Union, let us make two different hypotheses about its future. Let us assume first that the Soviet bureaucracy is overthrown by a revolutionary party having all the attributes of the old [[Bolshevism]], enriched moreover by the world experience of the recent period. Such a party would begin with the restoration of democracy in the [[trade unions]] and the [[Soviet (council)|Soviets]]. It would be able to, and would have to, restore [[Multi-party system|freedom of Soviet parties]]. Together with the masses, and at their head, it would carry out a ruthless purgation of the state apparatus. It would abolish [[Social class|ranks]] and [[Medal|decorations]], all kinds of privileges, and would limit inequality in the payment of labor to the life necessities of the economy and the state apparatus. It would give the youth free opportunity to think independently, learn, criticize and grow. It would introduce profound changes in the distribution of the national income in correspondence with the interests and will of the worker and peasant masses. But so far as concerns property relations, the new power would not have to resort to revolutionary measures. It would retain and further develop the experiment of [[planned economy]]. After the political revolution – that is, the deposing of the bureaucracy – the proletariat would have to introduce in the economy a series of very important reforms, but not another social revolution. If – to adopt a second hypothesis – a bourgeois party were to overthrow the ruling Soviet caste, it would find no small number of ready servants among the present bureaucrats, administrators, technicians, directors, party secretaries and privileged upper circles in general. A purgation of the state apparatus would, of course, be necessary in this case too. But a bourgeois restoration would probably have to clean out fewer people than a revolutionary party. The chief task of the new power would be to restore [[private property]] in the means of production. First of all, it would be necessary to create conditions for the development of strong farmers from the weak [[collective farm]]s, and for converting the strong collectives into producers' [[cooperative]]s of the bourgeois type into agricultural [[Joint stock company|stock companies]]. In the sphere of industry, denationalization would begin with the light industries and those producing food. The planning principle would be converted for the transitional period into a series of compromises between state power and individual "corporations" – potential proprietors, that is, among the Soviet captains of industry, the émigré former proprietors and foreign capitalists. Notwithstanding that the Soviet bureaucracy has gone far toward preparing a bourgeois restoration, the new regime would have to introduce in the matter of forms of property and methods of industry not a reform, but a social revolution. Let us assume to take a third variant – that neither a revolutionary nor a counterrevolutionary party seizes power. The bureaucracy continues at the head of the state. Even under these conditions social relations will not jell. We cannot count upon the bureaucracy's peacefully and voluntarily renouncing itself in behalf of socialist equality. If at the present time, notwithstanding the too obvious inconveniences of such an operation, it has considered it possible to introduce ranks and decorations, it must inevitably in future stages seek supports for itself in property relations. One may argue that the big bureaucrat cares little what are the prevailing forms of property, provided only they guarantee him the necessary income. This argument ignores not only the instability of the bureaucrat's own rights, but also the question of his descendants. The new cult of the family has not fallen out of the clouds. Privileges have only half their worth, if they cannot be transmitted to one's children. But the right of testament is inseparable from the [[right of property]]. It is not enough to be the director of a trust; it is necessary to be a [[stockholder]]. The victory of the bureaucracy in this decisive sphere would mean its conversion into a [[New class|new possessing class]]. On the other hand, the victory of the proletariat over the bureaucracy would insure a revival of the [[socialist revolution]]. The third variant consequently brings us back to the two first, with which, in the interests of clarity and simplicity, we set out.{{cite book | last = Trotsky | first = Leon | year = 1936 | title = The Revolution Betrayed | url = http://www.marxists.org/archive/trotsky/1936/revbet/ch09.htm#ch09-3 }}}} ===World War II=== In 1941 [[Adolf Hitler]] of [[Nazi Germany]] decided to attack the Soviet Union ([[Operation Barbarossa]]). In June 1941 the German [[Wehrmacht]] [[Eastern Front (World War II)|invaded the Soviet Union]], and the [[Red Army]] retreated. Military observers around the world watched closely. It appears that most of them shared Hitler's opinion, expecting Germany to win, destroy the Soviet system, and establish its [[New Order (political system)|New Order]] in Europe.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} Very few American experts thought the Soviet Union would survive.{{cite book | last = Herring Jr. | first = George C. | year = 1973 | title = Aid to Russia, 1941-1946: Strategy, diplomacy, the origins of the cold war | publisher = Columbia University Press | location = New York | isbn = 0-231-03336-2 | pages = 41, 47 }} After the beginning of the German invasion, the [[United States Department of War]] advised [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] that the German army would conquer the Soviet Union within one to three months.[[Ian Kershaw|Kershaw, Ian]] (2007). ''Fateful Choices: Ten Decisions That Changed The World 1940-1941'', p. 298. Penguin Books Ltd, London, United Kingdom. In July 1941, the American general staff issued memoranda to the American press that a Soviet collapse was to be expected within several weeks.Bahm, Karl (2001). Berlin 1945: The Final Reckoning'', p. 8. Amber Books Ltd. [[United Kingdom|British]] analysts also shared this view, believing that Germany would win within three to six weeks without heavy losses.Reynolds, David. ''From World War to Cold War: Churchill, Roosevelt and the International History of the 1940s'', p. 98. [[Oxford University Press]]. Negative predictions had an important impact on President Roosevelt; while the United States was not at the time at war, he favored the Allies (Britain and the Soviet Union), and decided to try to avert the collapse of the USSR by supplying them with munitions through [[Lend-Lease]], and also to pressure [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] not to attack while the USSR was so vulnerable. The [[Red Army]] [[Battle of Moscow|held the line]] at the outskirts of [[Moscow]] and predictions changed to "uncertain." ===Early Cold War=== ====George Orwell==== [[George Orwell]], author of ''[[Animal Farm]]'' and ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]'', wrote in 1946 that "''the Russian regime will either democratize itself or it will perish''".Orwell, George. "[[James Burnham and the Managerial Revolution]]." London: 1946. He was regarded by US historian [[Robert Conquest]] as one of the first people who made such a prediction. According to a Conquest article published in 1969, "In time, the Communist world is faced with a fundamental crisis. We can not say for certain that it will democratize itself. But every indication is that it will, as Orwell said, either democratize itself or perish...We must also, though, be prepared to cope with cataclysmic changes, for the death throes of the more backward apparatus may be destructive and dangerous".[[Robert Conquest]] ''The Dragons of Expectation. Reality and Delusion in the Course of History.'', W.W. Norton and Company (2004), {{ISBN|0-393-05933-2}}, page 217; citation from New York Times Magazine, August 18, 1969 ====George Kennan==== American diplomat [[George F. Kennan]] proposed his famous [[containment]] theory in 1946–47, arguing that, if the Soviet Union were not allowed to expand, it would soon collapse. In the [[X Article]] he wrote: {{quote|[T]he main element of any United States policy toward the Soviet Union must be a long-term, patient but firm and vigilant containment of Russian expansive tendencies... Soviet pressure against the free institutions of the Western world is something that can be constrained by the adroit and vigilant application of counter-force at a series of constantly shifting geographical and political points, corresponding to the shifts and manoeuvres of Soviet policy.{{cite journal | last = Kennan | first = George | authorlink = George F. Kennan |date=July 1947 | title = The Sources of Soviet conduct | journal = Foreign Affairs | volume = | issue = XXV | pages = 566–582 | url = | accessdate = }}}} The United States would have to undertake this containment alone and [[unilateralism|unilaterally]], but if it could do so without undermining its own economic health and political stability, the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Soviet party]] structure would undergo a period of immense strain eventually resulting in "either the break-up or the gradual mellowing of Soviet power." Kennan later regretted the manner in which his theory was received and implemented, but it nevertheless became a core element of American strategy, which consisted of building a series of [[military alliance]]s around the USSR.{{cite book | last = Kennan | first = George | authorlink = George F. Kennan | year = 1967 | title = Memoirs: 1925-1950 | publisher = | location = | pages = 354–367 }} ====Winston Churchill==== [[Winston Churchill]] made repeated claims about the imminent fall of the Soviet Union throughout his political career. In January 1920, he denounced Bolshevism as a "rule of men who in their insane vanity and conceit believe they are entitled to give a government to a people which the people loathe and detest... The attempt to carry into practice those wild theories can only be attended with universal confusion, corruption, disorder and civil war." Later, he made a similar prediction in a journal article in 1931. After World War II, speaking about the recently established Soviet satellite states in Eastern Europe, he stated in 1954: "The forces of the human spirit and of national character alive in those countries cannot be speedily extinguished even by large-scale movements of populations and mass education of children." And in the epilogue to the one volume edition of his World War II memoirs, published in 1957, Churchill wrote: "The natural forces are working with greater freedom and greater opportunity to fertilize and vary the thoughts and the power of individual men and women. They are far bigger and more pliant in the vast structure of a mighty empire than could ever have been conceived by Marx in his hovel... Human society will grow in many forms not comprehended by a party machine."Warren, Spencer. (1999) ''A Philosophy of International Politics in Churchill's "Iron Curtain" Speech Fifty Years Later'', University of Missouri Press, Columbia, MO. ====Zbigniew Brzezinski==== [[Zbigniew Brzezinski]], [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]] to U.S. President [[Jimmy Carter]], predicted the dissolution of the Soviet Union on several occasions. In a 2006 interview, Brzezinski stated that in his 1950 [[Master's degree|master's]] [[thesis]] (which has not been published) he argued that "the Soviet Union was pretending to be a [[Unitary state|single state]] but in fact it was a [[federation|multinational]] [[Soviet Empire|empire]] in the age of [[nationalism]]. So the Soviet Union would break up."{{cite web | last = Brzezinski | first = Zbigniew | authorlink = | date = March 20, 2006 | url = http://english.people.com.cn/200603/20/eng20060320_251953.html | title = "Agenda for constructive American-Chinese dialogue huge": Brzezinski | work = | publisher = People's Daily Online | accessdate = 2006-04-19 }} As an academic at [[Columbia University]], Brzezinski wrote [[Zbigniew Brzezinski#Bibliography|numerous books and articles]] that "took seriously the option of collapse", including ''Dilemmas of Change in Soviet Politics'' (1969) and ''Between Two Ages: America's Role in the Technetronic Era'' (1970).{{cite web|last=Melberg |first=Hans O. |authorlink= |year=1996 |url=http://geocities.com/hmelberg/papers/960409.htm |title=Organic explanations |work= |publisher= |accessdate=2006-04-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027111054/http://geocities.com/hmelberg/papers/960409.htm |archivedate=October 27, 2009 |deadurl=unfit }} ''Dilemmas of Change in Soviet Politics'' contained fourteen articles dealing with the future of the Soviet Union. Six of them, by Brzezinski himself, [[Robert Conquest]], [[Merle Fainsod]], [[Eugene Lyons]], Giorgio Galli, and [[Isaac Don Levine]], considered "collapse as a serious possibility although not immediately." {{cite journal |first=Seymour Martin |last=Lipset |authorlink= |author2=Gyorgy Bence |date=April 1994 |title=Anticipations of the failure of communism |journal=Theory and Society |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=169–210 |id=(Paper) 1573-7853 (Online) |url=http://bailey83221.livejournal.com/80804.html |doi=10.1007/BF00993814 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060502123923/http://bailey83221.livejournal.com/80804.html |archivedate=2006-05-02 |df= }} On the other hand, in 1976 Brzezinski predicted that the [[politics of the Soviet Union]] would be practically unchanged for several more generations to come:
A central question, however, is whether such [[social change]] [[[modernization]]] is capable of altering, or has in fact already altered in a significant fashion, the underlying character of Soviet politics. That character, as I have argued, has been shaped largely by political traditions derived from the specifics of [[History of Russia|Russian]] / [[History of the Soviet Union|Soviet history]], and it is deeply embedded in the operational style and institutions of the existing Soviet system. The ability of that system to resist [[History of the Soviet Union (1953-1985)#De-Stalinization and the Khrushchev era|de-Stalinization]] seems to indicate a considerable degree of resilience on the part of the dominant mode of politics in the Soviet context. It suggests, at the very least, that political changes are produced very slowly through social change, and that one must wait for at least several generations before social change begins to be significantly reflected in the political sphere.{{cite book | last = Brzezinski | first = Zbigniew | authorlink = Zbigniew Brzezinski | editor = Paul Cocks, Robert V. Daniels and Nancy Whittier Heer. | chapter = Soviet Politics: From the Future to the Past? | title = The Dynamics of Soviet Politics | publisher = Harvard University Press | location = Cambridge | pages = 337–51 | year = 1976 }}
In 1989, shortly before the fall of the Berlin Wall and the [[Revolutions of 1989|collapse of Soviet power]] throughout [[Eastern Europe]], Brzezinski published ''The Grand Failure: The Birth and Decay of Communism in the Twentieth Century''. In that work he wrote:
[[Marxist-Leninism]] is an alien doctrine imposed on the region by an imperial power whose rule is culturally repugnant to the dominated peoples. As a result, a process of organic rejection of communism by Eastern European societies – a phenomenon similar to the [[Human anatomy|human body]]'s [[Transplant rejection|rejection]] of a [[Organ transplant|transplanted organ]] – is underway."{{cite book | last = Brzezinski | first = Zbigniew | authorlink = Zbigniew Brzezinski | year = 1989 | title = The Grand Failure: The Birth and Death of Communism in the Twentieth Century | publisher = Charles Schribner's Sons | location = New York | isbn = 0-02-030730-6 | pages = 105 and 242–255 }}
Brzezinski went on to claim that communism "failed to take into account the basic human craving for [[Individualism|individual]] [[Freedom (philosophy)|freedom]]." He argued there were five possibilities for USSR: # Successful pluralization, # Protracted crisis, # Renewed [[Brezhnev stagnation|stagnation]], # [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt|Coup]] ([[KGB]], [[Military of the Soviet Union|Military]]), and # The explicit collapse of the [[Communist state|Communist regime]]. Option #5 in fact took place three years later, but at the time he wrote that collapse was "at this stage a much more remote possibility" than alternative #3: renewed stagnation. He also predicted chances of some form of communism existing in the Soviet Union in 2017 was a little more than 50%. Finally when the end did come in a few more decades, Brzezinski wrote, it would be "most likely turbulent." ====Ferenc Farkas de Kisbarnak==== [[Ferenc Farkas de Kisbarnak]], an exiled Hungarian general and leader of the [[Anti-Bolshevik Bloc of Nations]] (ABN), predicted the dissolution of the Soviet Union due to [[nationalist]] pressures. From June 12–14 of 1950, the Convention of the ABN was held in [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]] under the auspices of the Scottish League for European Freedom. At the conference, Farkas gave a speech entitled "The War Against Bolshevism and the Military Factors Represented by the Subjugated Nations" where he predicted the disintegration of the USSR along [[Demographics of the Soviet Union|ethnic lines]] which would eventually leave [[European Russia]] isolated. He predicted the eventual independence of [[Ukraine]], the [[Baltic states]], [[Turkestan]], the [[Idel-Ural]] republics, and [[Siberia]]. The third resolution of the ABN convention further called for "The destruction of Russian imperialism and the guarantee of world peace by splitting the USSR up and re-establishing on ethnic principles, the independent national states of all nations living under bolshevist oppression bearing among other things, in mind that whole national groups have been forcible [sic] deported and are awaiting the moment when they could return to their native land."[[National Library of Scotland]], [[Edinburgh]]. Acc. 10090, Papers of Dr [[Robert McIntyre|Robert Douglas McIntyre]], MB ChB, DPH, Duniv, JP. File 61: Correspondence with or papers received from East European national movements in exile (principally the Anti-Bolshevik Bloc of Nations and the Ukrainian Committee in Great Britain) and from John F Stewart of the Scottish League for European Freedom, 1952-6. Documents "Resolutions of the Convention of the Anti-Bolshevik Block of Nations (ABN) held in Edinburgh on the 12th, 13th, and 14th of June 1950, convoked under the auspices of the Scottish League for European Freedom", pg. 1, and "The War Against Bolshevism and the Military Factors Represented by the Subjugated Nations", pg. 6. Accessed 06 August 2014. ====Charles de Gaulle==== Only a handful of thinkers, ranging from French President [[Charles de Gaulle]] to the Soviet dissident [[Andrei Amalrik]], foretold the eventual dissolution of the Soviet Union itself, and even they saw it as likely to happen as a result of [[Sino-Russian relations#Soviet Union, Republic of China, People's Republic of China|disastrous wars]] with [[People's Republic of China|China]] or pressures from the [[Islam in the Soviet Union|Islamic]] [[Republics of the Soviet Union#Sorted by region|Soviet states]] of [[Central Asia]].{{cite journal |first=David |last=Fromkin |authorlink= |date=November 9, 1999 |title=Communists lost their faith, and failed to convert to democracy |journal=[[The Plain Dealer]] ([[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]]) |volume= |issue= |pages=9B |url=http://bailey83221.livejournal.com/78948.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060531100949/http://bailey83221.livejournal.com/78948.html |archivedate=May 31, 2006 |df= }} On 23 November 1959, in a speech in [[Strasbourg]], de Gaulle announced his vision for Europe: ''[[Charles de Gaulle#1958—1962: Founding of the Fifth Republic|Oui, c'est l'Europe, depuis l'Atlantique jusqu'à l'Oural, c'est toute l'Europe, qui décidera du destin du monde.]]'' ("Yes, it is Europe, from the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] to the [[Ural Mountains|Urals]], it is Europe, it is the whole of Europe, that will decide the destiny of the world."){{cite web |last = |first = |authorlink = |url = http://www.charles-de-gaulle.org/article.php3?id_article=375 |title = Sur l'Europe |work = Citations |publisher = Charles-de-Gaulle.org |accessdate = 2006-04-19 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060522001018/http://www.charles-de-gaulle.org/article.php3?id_article=375 |archivedate = 2006-05-22 |df = }} This phrase has been interpreted in various ways—on the one hand, as offering [[détente]] to the USSR,{{cite web |last = |first = |authorlink = |url = http://www.charles-de-gaulle.org/article.php3?id_article=375 |title = 1962-1968 : the consolidation of the regime |work = Biography |publisher = Charles-de-Gaulle.org |accessdate = 2006-04-19 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060522001018/http://www.charles-de-gaulle.org/article.php3?id_article=375 |archivedate = 2006-05-22 |df = }} on the other, as predicting the collapse of communism throughout Eastern Europe.{{cite news | first=Zbigniew | last=Brzezinski | title=The West Adrift: Vision In Search of A Strategy | publisher=Washington Post | pages=C1 | date=March 1, 1992 }}{{cite news | author=Valerio Castronovo | title=Russia Is Close, But the Kremlin Is Not | publisher=Il Sole 24 Ore | date=29 June 2002 }} ====Konrad Adenauer==== [[Konrad Adenauer]] has been cited predicting the [[German reunification|reunification of Germany]] as early as the 1950s,{{cite news | first=Paul | last=Greenberg | title=The forgotten giant | publisher=[[Arkansas Democrat-Gazette]] | page=J4 | date=November 28, 1999 }} but according to Hans-Peter Schwarz, in the last few years of Adenauer's life he repeatedly said that Soviet power would last a long time.{{cite book | last = Schwarz | first = Hans-Peter | title = Konrad Adenauer: A German Politician and Statesman in a Period of War, Revolution and Reconstruction : The Statesman : 1952-1967, Volume 2 | origyear = 1995 | publisher = Berghahn Books | isbn = 1-57181-960-6 | page = 795 | year = 1997 }} In 1966, at the [[Christian Democratic Union (Germany)|Christian Democrats]]' [[party conference]], Adenauer stated his hopes that some day the Soviets might allow the reunification of Germany. Some analysts say it might be considered a prediction:
I have not given up hope. One day Soviet Russia will recognize that the division of Germany, and with it the division of Europe, is not to its advantage. We must be watchful for when the moment comes... we must not let it go unexploited.
====Whittaker Chambers==== In a posthumously published 1964 book entitled ''Cold Friday'', Communist [[Defection|defector]] [[Whittaker Chambers]] predicted an eventual Soviet collapse beginning with a "[[satellite state|satellite]] revolution" in Eastern Europe. This revolution would then result in the transformation of the Soviet [[dictatorship]]. {{Cite book | surname = Chambers | given = Whittaker | authorlink = | title = Cold Friday | publisher = Random House | year = 1964 | page = 315}} ====Michel Garder==== [[Michel Garder]] was a French author who predicted the dissolution of the Soviet Union in the book ''L'Agonie du Regime en Russie Sovietique'' (''[[Michel Garder#The Death Struggle of the Regime in Soviet Russia|The Death Struggle of the Regime in Soviet Russia]]'') (1965). He set the date of the collapse for 1970. ===Détente=== ====RAND corporation==== In 1968 Egon Neuberger, of the [[RAND|RAND Corporation]], predicted that "[t]he [[central economy|centrally planned economy]] eventually would meet its demise, because of its demonstrably growing ineffectiveness as a system for managing a modernizing economy in a rapidly changing world."Cahn, Anne H. (September 1998). ''Killing Détente: The Right Attacks the CIA'', Pennsylvania State University Press. {{ISBN|0-271-01791-0}}
*Egon Neuberger, "The Legacies of Central Planning," RM 5530-PR, [[RAND Corporation|Rand]], June 1968, quoted in Gertrude E. Schroeder, "Reflections on Economic Sovietology," ''Post-Soviet Affairs'' 11 (July–September 1995): 197–234. ====Robert Conquest==== In the book ''Dilemmas of Change in Soviet Politics'', which was a collection of authors edited by [[Zbigniew Brzezinski]], [[Robert Conquest]] in his section, "Immobilism and decay", saw "the USSR as a country where the political system is radically and dangerously inappropriate to its social and economic dynamics. This is a formula for change - change which may be sudden and catastrophic." Conquest also predicted the fall in his book, ''The Nation Killers: The Soviet Deportation of Nationalities'' (1970).{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} ====Sun Myung Moon==== [[Sun Myung Moon]], founder of the [[Unification Church]] repeatedly predicted that Communism was inherently flawed and would inevitably collapse sometime in the late 1980s. In a speech to followers in Paris in April 1972, he stated: "Communism, begun in 1917, could maintain itself approximately 60 years and reach its peak. So 1978 is the borderline and afterward communism will decline; in the 70th year it will be altogether ruined. This is true. Therefore now is the time for people who are studying communism to abandon it." {{cite web|url=http://www.tparents.org/library/unification/talks/ward/ward%2D000000.htm |title=Endowed With A Sense Of History - Thomas J Ward |publisher=Tparents.org |accessdate=2010-09-19}} ====Andrei Amalrik==== In 1969, prominent dissident [[Andrei Amalrik]] wrote in his book ''[[Andrei Amalrik#Will the Soviet Union Survive Until 1984?|Will the Soviet Union Survive Until 1984?]]'': :There is another powerful factor which works against the chance of any kind of peaceful reconstruction and which is equally negative for all levels of society: this is the extreme isolation in which the regime has placed both society and itself. This isolation has not only separated the regime from society, and all sectors of society from each other, but also put the country in extreme isolation from the rest of the world. This isolation has created for all—from the bureaucratic elite to the lowest social levels—an almost surrealistic picture of the world and of their place in it. Yet the longer this state of affairs helps to perpetuate the status quo, the more rapid and decisive will be its collapse when confrontation with reality becomes inevitable. Amalrik predicted the collapse of the regime would occur between 1980 and 1985.Cahn, Anne H. (September 1998). ''Killing Détente: The Right Attacks the CIA'', Pennsylvania State University Press. {{ISBN|0-271-01791-0}}
*[[Andrei Amalrik]], ''[[Andrei Amalrik#Will the Soviet Union Survive Until 1984?|Will the Soviet Union Survive Until 1984?]]'' (New York: Harper & Row, 1970), 33. {{ISBN|0-06-090732-0}} The year in the title was after the [[Nineteen Eighty-Four|novel of the same name]]. Soviet authorities were skeptical. [[Natan Sharansky]] explained that "in 1984 [[KGB]] officials, on coming to me in prison" when Amalrik's prediction was mentioned, "laughed at this prediction. Amalrik is long dead, they said, but we are still very much present."{{cite news | first= | last= | author= | url= | title=Press conference with Natan Sharansky, Israel's minister for trade and industry | work= | publisher=Official Kremlin International News Broadcast | pages= | page= | date=29 January 1996 | accessdate=}} ====Marian Kamil Dziewanowski==== Historian [[Marian Kamil Dziewanowski]] "gave a lecture titled 'Death of the Soviet Regime' at the Russian Research Center at [[Harvard University]]. The same lecture was delivered at [[Cambridge University]] in [[England]] in 1971 and 1979. The text of the lecture (titled 'Death of the Soviet Regime: a Study in American Sovietology, by a Historian') was published in ''Studies in Soviet Thought''. In 1980, he "updated this study and delivered it as a paper at the International Slavic Congress at [[Garmisch-Partenkirchen|Garmish]]; titled 'The Future of Soviet Russia,' it was published in ''Coexistence: An International Journal'' (Glasgow 1982)."{{cite journal | first =M.K. | last =Dziewanowski | authorlink =Marian Kamil Dziewanowski |date=January 1999 | title =Letters | journal = The Sarmatian Review | volume =19 | issue =1 | pages = | url =http://www.ruf.rice.edu/~sarmatia/199/letters.html }} ====Emmanuel Todd==== [[Emmanuel Todd]] attracted attention in 1976 when he predicted the fall of the Soviet Union, based on indicators such as increasing [[infant mortality]] rates: ''[[Emmanuel Todd#Prediction of the collapse of the USSR|La chute finale: Essais sur la décomposition de la sphère Soviétique]]'' (The Final Fall: an Essay on the Disintegration of the Soviet Sphere). ====Bernard Levin==== [[Bernard Levin]] drew attention in 1992 to his prophetic article originally published in ''[[The Times]]'' in September 1977, in which an uncannily accurate prediction of the appearance of new faces in the [[Politburo]] was made, resulting in radical but peaceful political change.{{cite journal | author = Bernard Levin |date=Spring 1993 | title = One who got it right | journal = [[The National Interest]] | pages = 64–65 | url = http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2751/is_n31/ai_13991692 | accessdate = 2006-04-21 }} ====Daniel Patrick Moynihan==== [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Daniel Patrick Moynihan]] in a series of articles and interviews from 1975 onward discussed the possibility, indeed likelihood, of the breakup of the Soviet Empire. But Moynihan also expressed the view that [[liberal democracy]], too, faced an uncertain future. He argued in January 1975 that the Soviet Union was so weak economically, and so divided ethnically, that it could not long survive. However he said it "might have considerable time left before ethnicity breaks it up." By 1984 he argued "the Soviet idea is spent. History is moving away from it at astounding speed."{{cite news | first=Daniel Patrick | last=Moynihan | title=The Peace Dividend | publisher=[[New York Review of Books]] | date=28 June 1990 }} Some of his essays were published as ''Secrecy: The American Experience'' in 1999. ====Hélène Carrère d'Encausse==== In her 1978 book ''L'Empire éclaté'', [[historian]] (and later member of the [[Académie française]] and the [[European Parliament]]) [[Hélène Carrère d'Encausse]] predicted that the Soviet Union's political legitimacy would be fatally strained by diverging fertility between its culturally [[Russian people|Russian]]/[[Eastern European]] parts (dominant in government and industry but with plummeting birth rates) and its culturally [[Asia]]n and/or [[Muslim]] parts (with growing birth rates but little representation in the established "[[gerontocracy]]").{{cite book|last1=Carrère d'Encausse|first1=Hélène|title=L'Empire éclaté : la révolte des nations en URSS|date=1978|publisher=Flammarion|location=Paris|isbn=2-08-064090-9|language=French}} ''L'Empire éclaté'' generated substantial media interest at the time, winning the 1978 [[:fr:Prix Aujourd'hui|Prix Aujourd′hui]].{{cite web|title=Le prix Aujourd'hui à Hélène Carrère d'Encausse pour ''L'Empire éclaté''|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/archives/article/1978/11/08/le-prix-aujourd-hui-a-helene-carrere-d-encausse-pour-l-empire-eclate_2997033_1819218.html|website=lemonde.fr|date=8 November 1978}}. ====Samizdat==== Various essays published in [[samizdat]] in the early 1970s were on similar lines, some quite specifically predicting the end of the Soviet Union.S. Zorin and N. Alekseev, Vremya ne zhdet (Frankfurt, 1970); Alexander Petrov-Agatov (manuscript), excerpts in Cornelia Gerstenmaier, Die Stimme der Stummen (Stuttgart, 1971), 156-67. ====Hillel Ticktin/''Critique''==== In 1973 the Marxist, [[Hillel H. Ticktin]], wrote that the Soviet "system is sinking deeper into crisis".[https://www.scribd.com/search?query=ticktin+ussr Hillel Ticktin, 'Towards a Political Economy of the USSR'], ''Critique'' No.1. In 1976 he entitled an article: "The USSR: the Beginning of the End?".Hillel Ticktin, ''Critique'' No.7, p88. In 1978 he predicted that the [[Soviet Union]] would "break asunder and develop either to capitalism or to socialism".[https://www.scribd.com/doc/54949537/Class-Structure-of-the-USSR-and-the-Elite-by-Hillel-Ticktin Hillel Ticktin, 'The Class Structure of the USSR and the Elite'], ''Critique'' No.9, p61. And in 1983 he wrote that "the system is drawing to a close".Hillel Ticktin, ''Critique'' No.16, p121. (For a summary of Ticktin's approach, see Wikipedia's [[Stalinism]] entry.) ===Late Cold War=== ====Raymond Aron==== [[David Fromkin]] wrote of [[Raymond Aron]]'s prediction,
I know of only one person who came close to getting it right: Raymond Aron, the French philosopher and [[liberalism|liberal]] [[Anti-communism|anti-Communist]]. In a talk on the Soviet threat that I heard him give in the 1980s at the [[International Institute for Strategic Studies]] in [[London]], he reminded the audience of [[Niccolò Machiavelli|Machiavelli]]'s observation in ''[[The Prince]]'' that 'all armed prophets have conquered and all unarmed ones failed.' But what happens, Aron asked, if the prophet, having conquered and then ruled by force of arms, loses faith in his own prophecy? In the answer to that question, Aron suggested, lay the key to understanding the future of the Soviet Union.
====Ravi Batra==== The economist [[Ravi Batra]] predicted the collapse of the USSR in his 1978 book ''[[The Downfall of Capitalism and Communism]]''. ====Randall Collins==== In 1980 the sociologist [[Randall Collins]] presented his paper "The future decline of the Russian empire" at the [[University of South Florida]] and at [[Columbia University]] and published his predictions in the book "Weberian sociological theory" (1986). ====Robert M. Cutler==== In 1980, the political scientist Robert M. Cutler published an article "Soviet Dissent under Khrushchev"{{cite journal | last = Cutler | first = Robert | authorlink = Robert M Cutler |date=October 1980 | title = Soviet Dissent under Khrushchev: An Analytical Study | journal = Comparative Politics | volume = 10 | issue = 1 | pages = 15–35 | url = http://www.robertcutler.org/ar80cpx.htm#excerpt | accessdate = 4 July 2010 | doi = 10.2307/421761 }} that concluded that the following events were likely: (1) that in the generational turnover of elites after Brezhnev died (which began when he died in 1982), the Soviet regime would seek to increase public participation (which began in 1985 via [[glasnost]], after 2 more top gerontocrats had died); (2) that the Communist Party's rule would be challenged in Central Asia (which occurred in the 1986 rioting in Kazakhstan before the Baltic republics erupted); and (3) that Party leaders at the local level would go their own way if the Party did not give them a reason to remain loyal to the Moscow center (which occurred in all republics in the late 1980s, but most dramatically when the new RCP and RSFSR sapped some of the power of the CPSU and USSR in 1990-1991). ====James Dale Davidson and William Rees-Mogg==== [[James Dale Davidson]] and [[William Rees-Mogg]] predicted the collapse of the Soviet Union in their book [[The Great Reckoning]] in the early 1980s. ====Robert Gates==== [[Stewart Brand]] said when introducing the work of [[Philip Tetlock]] that Brand's partner had given a talk in the 1980s to top [[Central Intelligence Agency]] people about the future of the Soviet Union. One scenario he raised was that the Soviet bloc might break up; a sign of this happening would be the rise of unknown Mikhail Gorbachev through the party ranks. A CIA analyst said that the presentation was fine, but there was no way the Soviet Union was going to break up in his lifetime or his children's lifetime. The analyst's name was [[Robert Gates]].[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/apr/13/brain-food-political-forecasting Guardian newspaper, article on political and economic forecasting, 13 April 2010] On the other hand, in hearings before the U.S. Senate on March 19, 1986, when Gates (then head of the CIA's Directorate of Intelligence) was asked "what kind of work the Intelligence Community was doing to prepare policymakers for the consequences of change in the Soviet Union," he responded: "Quite frankly, without any hint that such fundamental change is going on, my resources do not permit me the luxury of sort of just idly speculating on what a different kind of Soviet Union might look like."Cited on page 114 of {{cite book |last1=Jones |first1=Milo L. and |last2=Silberzahn |first2=Philippe|year=2013 |title=Constructing Cassandra, Reframing Intelligence Failure at the CIA, 1947-2001|publisher=Stanford University Press |isbn=978-0804793360}} ====Anatoliy Golitsyn==== In 1984, [[Anatoliy Golitsyn]], an important KGB defector published the book ''New Lies For Old'',[http://www.premier1.net/~barkonwd/golitsyn.htm Anatoly Golitsyn, ''New Lies for Old''] wherein he predicted the collapse of the communist bloc orchestrated from above. He claimed this collapse was part of a long-term [[deception]] strategy designed to lull the West into a false sense of security, abolish all containment policies, and in time finally economically cripple and diplomatically isolate the [[United States]]. Among other things, Golitsyn stated: * "The 'liberalization' [in the Soviet Union] would be spectacular and impressive. Formal pronouncements might be made about a reduction in the communist party's role; its monopoly would be apparently curtailed." * "If [liberalization] should be extended to [[East Germany]], demolition of the [[Berlin Wall]] might even be contemplated." * "The [[European Parliament]] might become an all-European socialist parliament with representation from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. 'Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals' would turn out to be a neutral, socialist Europe." Collaborating opinions can be found in an archive of classified documents collected by [[Vladimir Bukovsky]], a defector also.Bukovsky, Vladimir, Judgement in Moscow, 1999 ====John le Carré==== [[John le Carré]] is a writer of fiction, but his "spy novels" are known for their keen insights on East-West relations in general and conflicts between Western and Soviet intelligence services in particular. In ''[[The Russia House]]'', published on May 22, 1989, there is the telling quote: "The Soviet Knight is dying inside his armour." ====Werner Obst==== In 1985 German economist [[Werner Obst]] published a book entitled ''Der Rote Stern verglüht. Moskaus Abstieg - Deutschlands Chance'' (The Red Star is Dying Away. Moscow's Decline - Germany's Chance), Munich: Wirtschaftsverlag Langen-Müller/Herbig, third edition in 1987, in which he predicted the collapse of the [[Soviet bloc]] and the reunification of [[Germany]] within the immediate future for about 1990, based on the analysis of economical statistics and trends. ====Ronald Reagan==== [[President of the United States|United States President]] [[Ronald Reagan]], throughout his 1980 election campaign and first term in office presented a public view that the Soviet Union had been growing in power relative to the United States. In 1981 he stated that "the Soviet Union has been engaged in the greatest military buildup in the history of man."Beth A. Fischer ''The Reagan Reversal: Foreign Policy and the End of the Cold War.'' University of Missouri Press, 2000 pg. 20 and the next year stated that "on balance the Soviet Union does have a definite margin of superiority" compared to the U.S. military.Beth A. Fischer ''The Reagan Reversal: Foreign Policy and the End of the Cold War.'' University of Missouri Press, 2000 pg. 21 The Reagan administration used a perceived strength of the Soviet Union to justify a significant expansion of military spending according to David Arbel and Ran Edelist. In their study ''Western Intelligence and the dissolution of the Soviet Union'' they argue it was this position by the Reagan administration that prevented the American intelligence agencies from predicting the demise of the USSR. Arbel and Edelist further argued that CIA analysts were encouraged to present any information exaggerating the Soviet threat and justifying the military buildup, while contrary evidence of Soviet weakness was ignored and those presenting it sidelined.David Arbel and Ran Edelist ''Western Intelligence and the dissolution of the Soviet Union, 1980-1990'' Routledge, 2003 pg. 160 At the same time Reagan expressed a long range view that the Soviet Union could eventually be defeated. On March 3, 1983, President Reagan told the [[National Association of Evangelicals]] in [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], [[Florida]]: "I believe that communism is another sad, bizarre chapter in human history whose last — last pages even now are being written."{{cite web |last = Reagan |first = Ronald |authorlink = |date = March 8, 1983 |url = http://www.reagansheritage.org/reagan/html/reagan03_08_83.shtml |title = Remarks at the Annual Convention of the National Association of Evangelicals in Orlando Florida |work = |publisher = |accessdate = 2008-05-30 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081006182135/http://www.reagansheritage.org/reagan/html/reagan03_08_83.shtml |archivedate = October 6, 2008 |df = }} In his June 1982 address to the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|British Parliament]] he stated:
It is the Soviet Union that runs against the tide of history by denying human freedom and human dignity to its citizens. It also is in deep economic difficulty. The rate of growth in the national product has been steadily declining since the fifties and is less than half of what it was then. The dimensions of this failure are astounding: A country which employs one-fifth of its population in agriculture is unable to feed its own people. Were it not for the private sector, the tiny private sector tolerated in Soviet agriculture, the country might be on the brink of famine.... Overcentralized, with little or no incentives, year after year the Soviet system pours its best resource into the making of instruments of destruction. The constant shrinkage of economic growth combined with the growth of military production is putting a heavy strain on the Soviet people. What we see here is a political structure that no longer corresponds to its economic base, a society where productive forces are hampered by political ones. ...In the Communist world as well, man's instinctive desire for freedom and self-determination surfaces again and again. To be sure, there are grim reminders of how brutally the police state attempts to snuff out this quest for [[self-governance|self-rule]] – [[Uprising of 1953 in East Germany|1953 in East Germany]], [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956|1956 in Hungary]], [[Prague Spring|1968 in Czechoslovakia]], [[1981 warning strike in Poland|1981 in Poland]]. But the struggle continues in Poland. And we know that there are even those who strive and suffer for freedom within the confines of the Soviet Union itself. ...What I am describing now is a plan and a hope for the long term – the march of freedom and democracy which will leave Marxism-Leninism on the [[ash heap of history]] as it has left other tyrannies which stifle the freedom and muzzle the self-expression of the people. And that's why we must continue our efforts to strengthen [[NATO]] even as we move forward with our Zero-Option initiative in the negotiations on intermediate-range forces and our proposal for a one-third reduction in [[Strategic bomber|strategic]] [[ballistic missile]] [[warhead]]s.{{cite web | last = Reagan | first = Ronald | authorlink = | date = June 8, 1982 | url = http://www.historyplace.com/speeches/reagan-parliament.htm | title = Ronald Reagan Address to British Parliament | work = | publisher = | accessdate = 2006-04-19 }}
Analyst Jeffrey W. Knopf has argued that Reagan went beyond everyone else:
Reagan stands out in part because he believed the Soviet Union could be defeated. For most of the Cold War, [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] administrations alike had assumed the Soviet Union would prove durable for the foreseeable future. The bipartisan policy of containment aimed to keep the Soviet Union in check while trying to avoid [[Nuclear warfare|nuclear war]]; it did not seek to force the dissolution of the Soviet empire. Ronald Reagan, in contrast, believed that the [[Economy of the Soviet Union|Soviet economy]] was so weak that increased pressure could bring the Soviet Union to the brink of failure. He therefore periodically expressed confidence that the forces of democracy 'will leave Marxism-Leninism on the ash heap of history'.
====P.R. Sarkar==== The leader of the Ananda Marga cult in West Bengal, [[P.R. Sarkar]], predicted in the 1980s that Soviet Communism would fall with "a few blows from the hammer". He cited "inner and external stasis" as major weaknesses of communism.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} ====Ruhollah Khomeini==== On 7 January 1989, [[Ruhollah Khomeini|Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini]], supreme leader of the [[Iranian Revolution|Iran]], sent a [[Khomeini's letter to Mikhail Gorbachev|letter]] to [[Mikhail Gorbachev]], the General Secretary of the [[Soviet Union]].{{cite news|title=Imam Khomeini's historic epistle to Gorbachev|url=http://english.irib.ir/analysis/articles2/item/85596-imam-khomeinis-historic-epistle-to-gorbachev|accessdate=3 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170422114303/http://english.irib.ir/analysis/articles2/item/85596-imam-khomeinis-historic-epistle-to-gorbachev|archive-date=2017-04-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} This letter was Khomeini's only written message to a foreign leader.{{cite book|author=Melvin Allan Goodman|title=Gorbachev's Retreat: The Third World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YmkC_hWeVaEC&pg=PA61|year=1991|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-93696-9|pages=61}} Khomeini's letter was delivered by the Iranian politicians [[Abdollah Javadi-Amoli]], [[Mohammad-Javad Larijani]], and [[Marzieh Hadidchi]]. In the letter, Khomeini declared that [[Communism]] was dissolving within the Soviet bloc,{{cite book|author=Michael Axworthy|title=Revolutionary Iran: A History of the Islamic Republic|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XYoeAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA301|year=2013|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-932226-8|pages=301}} and invited Gorbachev to consider Islam as an alternative to communist ideology.{{cite book|title=The Greatest Jihād: Combat with the Self|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rv065uRyCasC&pg=PR15|year=2003|publisher=Alhoda UK|isbn=978-964-335-557-9|pages=15–}} ==Why were Sovietologists wrong?== According to Kevin Brennan: {{quote|[[Kremlinology|Sovietology]] failed because it operated in an environment that encouraged failure. Sovietologists of all political stripes were given strong incentives to ignore certain facts and focus their interest in other areas. I don't mean to suggest that there was a giant conspiracy at work; there wasn't. It was just that there were no careers to be had in questioning the conventional wisdom... ..There were other kinds of institutional biases as well, such as those that led to the...|[[Team B]]" Report."{{cite web | last = Brennan | first = Kevin | authorlink = | year = 2004 | url = http://www.la-mancha.net/?p=159 | title = Tilting at Windmills: On The Failure of Sovietology | work = www.la-mancha.net | publisher = | accessdate = 2006-04-21 }}}} [[Seymour Martin Lipset]] and [[György Bence]] write: {{quote|Given these judgments of the Soviet future made by political leaders and journalists, the question is why were they right and so many of our Sovietological colleagues wrong. The answer again in part must be ideological. Reagan and Levin came from rightist backgrounds, and Moynihan, much like the leaders of the [[AFL-CIO]], from a [[left-wing politics|leftist]] anti-[[Stalinism|Stalinist]] [[Social democracy|social-democratic]] milieu, environments that disposed participants to believe the worst. Most of the Sovietologists, on the other hand, were left-liberal in their politics, an orientation that undermined their capacity to accept the view that economic statism, planning, socialist incentives, would not work. They were also for the most part ignorant of, or ignored, the basic [[Marxism|Marxist]] formulation that it is impossible to build socialism in impoverished societies. Brzezinski's 1969 collection, ''Dilemmas of Change in Soviet Politics'' demonstrates this point, of "the fourteen contributors...Two-thirds (four out of six) of those who foresaw a serious possibility of breakdown were, like [[Bernard Levin|Levin]] and [[Daniel Patrick Moynihan|Moynihan]], nonacademics. Three quarters (six out of eight) of those who could not look beyond system continuity were scholars.}} [[Richard Pipes]] took a slightly different view, situating the failure of the Sovietological profession in the larger context of the failures of Social Science:
It seems likely that ultimately the reason for the failure of professionals to understand the Soviet predicament lay in their indifference to the human factor. In the desire to emulate the successes of the natural scientists, whose judgments are "value free," politology (sic) and sociology have been progressively dehumanized, constructing model and relying on statistics (many of them falsified) and, in the process, losing contact with the subject of their inquiries—the messy, contradictory, unpredictable homo sapiens.Cited on pages 125 and 126 of {{cite book |last1=Jones |first1=Milo L. and |last2=Silberzahn |first2=Philippe|year=2013 |title=Constructing Cassandra, Reframing Intelligence Failure at the CIA, 1947-2001|publisher=Stanford University Press |isbn=978-0804793360}}

{{for|the film adaptations of the play|Saint Joan (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox play | name = Saint Joan | image = Saint Joan (play).gif | image_size = 225px | caption = Constable & Co., Ltd. cover, 1924 | writer = [[George Bernard Shaw]] | genre = Drama | setting = 15th century France | subject = | premiere = 28 December 1923 | place = [[Garrick Theatre (New York City)|Garrick Theatre]]
[[Manhattan]], New York City | orig_lang = English }} '''''Saint Joan''''' is a play by [[George Bernard Shaw]] about 15th century French military figure [[Joan of Arc]]. Premiering in 1923, three years after her [[Canonization of Joan of Arc|canonization]] by the [[Roman Catholic Church]], the play dramatises what is known of her life based on the substantial records of her [[Trial of Joan of Arc|trial]]. Shaw studied the transcripts and decided that the concerned people acted in good faith according to their beliefs. He wrote in his [[preface]] to the play:
There are no villains in the piece. Crime, like disease, is not interesting: it is something to be done away with by general consent, and that is all [there is] about it. It is what men do at their best, with good intentions, and what normal men and women find that they must and will do in spite of their intentions, that really concern us.
[[Michael Holroyd]] has characterised the play as "a tragedy without villains" and also as Shaw's "only tragedy".{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2007/jul/14/theatre.stage | title=A tragedy without villains | work=The Guardian | authorlink = Michael Holroyd | last = Holroyd | first = Michael | date=14 July 2007 | accessdate=2009-01-18}} John Fielden has discussed further the appropriateness of characterising ''Saint Joan'' as a tragedy.{{cite journal | last=Fielden | first=John | title=Shaw's ''Saint Joan'' as Tragedy | journal=Twentieth-Century Literature | volume=3 | issue=2 | pages=59–67 | date=July 1957 | doi=10.2307/441003 | publisher=Hofstra University | jstor=441003}} The text of the published play includes a long Preface by Shaw. ==Characters== {{col-begin}}{{col-break}} * [[Robert de Baudricourt]] * [[Jean de Metz|Steward to de Baudricourt]] * [[Joan of Arc|Joan]] * [[Bertrand de Poulengy]] * [[Georges de la Trémoille|De la Trémouille]], [[Grand Chamberlain of France|Lord Chamberlain]] * [[Catherine de L'Isle-Bouchard|Duchess de la Trémouille]] * [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Reims|Archbishop of Rheims]] * [[Gilles de Rais|Gilles de Rais ("Bluebeard")]] * [[La Hire|Captain La Hire]] * [[Pierre Cauchon|Bishop of Beauvais]] * [[Charles VII of France|Dauphin, Charles VII]] {{col-break|gap=2em}} * [[Richard de Beauchamp, 13th Earl of Warwick|Earl of Warwick]] * [[Jean de Dunois|Dunois, Bastard of Orléans]] * [[Page (servant)|Page]] to Dunois * John de Stogumber, English [[chaplain]] * [[Canon (priest)|Canon]] John D'Estivet * Canon de Courcelles * [[Brother (Christian)|Brother]] Martin Ladvenu * Brother John Lemaître, The [[Inquisitor]] * [[Executioner]] * English [[Soldier]] * [[Gentleman]] {{col-end}} ==Plot== Shaw characterised ''Saint Joan'' as "A Chronicle Play in 6 Scenes and an Epilogue ". Joan, a simple peasant girl, claims to experience visions of [[Margaret the Virgin|Saint Margaret]], [[Catherine of Alexandria|Saint Catherine]], and the archangel [[Michael (archangel)|Michael]], which she says were sent by God to guide her conduct. Scene 1 (23 February 1429): Robert de Baudricourt complains about the inability of [[Poultry|the hens]] on his [[farm]] to produce [[Egg as food|eggs]]. Joan claims that her voices are telling her to lift the siege of [[Orléans]], and to allow her several of his men for this purpose. Joan also says that she will crown the [[Dauphin of France|Dauphin]] in [[Reims Cathedral]]. De Baudricourt ridicules Joan, but his Steward feels inspired by her words. De Baudricourt eventually begins to feel the same sense of inspiration, and gives his consent to Joan. The Steward enters at the end of the scene to exclaim that the hens have begun to lay eggs again. De Baudricourt interprets this as a sign from God of Joan's divine inspiration. Scene 2 (8 March 1429): Joan talks her way into being received at the court of the weak and vain Dauphin. There, she tells him that her voices have commanded her to help him become a true king by rallying his troops to drive out the English occupiers and restore France to greatness. Joan succeeds in doing this through her excellent powers of flattery, negotiation, leadership, and skill on the battlefield. Scene 3 (29 April 1429): Dunois and his page are waiting for the wind to turn so that he and his forces can lay [[Siege of Orleans|siege to Orléans]]. Joan and Dunois commiserate, and Dunois attempts to explain to her more pragmatic realities of an attack, without the wind at their back. Her replies eventually inspire Dunois to rally the forces, and at the scene's end, the wind turns in their favour. Scene 4 (June 1429): Warwick and de Stogumber discuss Joan's stunning series of victories. Joined by the Bishop of Beauvais, they are at a loss to explain her success. De Stogumber decides Joan is a [[Witchcraft|witch]]. Beauvais sees Joan as a threat to the Church, as she claims to receive instructions from God directly. He fears she wants to instill [[Nationalism|national pride]] in the people, which would undermine the Church's universal rule. Warwick thinks she wants to create a system in which the [[king]] is responsible to God only, ultimately stripping him and other [[Feudalism|feudal lords]] of their power. All agree that she must die. Scene 5 (17 July 1429): the Dauphin is [[Coronation of the French monarch|crowned]] Charles VII at [[Reims Cathedral]]. A perplexed Joan asks Dunois why she is so unpopular at [[Court (royal)|court]]. He explains that she has exposed [[Very important person|very important people]] as incompetent and irrelevant. She talks to him, Bluebeard, and La Hire about returning [[Domrémy-la-Pucelle|home]]. Charles, who complains about the weight of his coronation robes and smell of the [[Chrism|holy oil]], is pleased to hear this. She then says to Dunois "Before I go home, let's take Paris", an idea which horrifies Charles, who wants to negotiate [[Peace treaty|a peace]] immediately. The Archbishop berates her for her "sin of pride". Dunois warns her that if she is captured on a [[Military campaign|campaign]] he deems foolhardy, no one will [[ransom]] or rescue her. Now realizing that she is "alone on earth", Joan declares that she will gain the strength to do what she must from the people and from God. She leaves, leaving the men dumbfounded. Scene 6 (30 May 1431): deals with her trial. De Stogumber is adamant that she be executed at once. The Inquisitor, the Bishop of Beauvais, and the Church officials on both sides of the trial have a long discussion on the nature of her [[heresy]]. Joan is brought to the court, and continues to assert that her voices speak to her directly from God and that she has no need of the [[Hierarchy of the Catholic Church|Church's officials]]. This outrages de Stogumber. She acquiesces to the pressure of torture at the hands of her oppressors, and agrees to sign a confession relinquishing the truth behind her voices. When she learns she will be imprisoned for life without hope of parole, she renounces her confession:
Joan: "You think that life is nothing but not being dead? It is not the bread and water I fear. I can live on bread. It is no hardship to drink water if the water be clean. But to shut me from the light of the sky and the sight of the fields and flowers; to chain my feet so that I can never again climb the hills. To make me breathe foul damp darkness, without these things I cannot live. And by your wanting to take them away from me, or from any human creature, I know that your council is of the devil."
Joan accepts [[Death by burning|death at the stake]] as preferable to such an imprisoned existence. De Stogumber vehemently demands that Joan then be taken to the stake for immediate execution. The Inquisitor and the Bishop of Beauvais [[Excommunication|excommunicate]] her and deliver her into the hands of the English. The Inquisitor asserts that Joan was fundamentally innocent, in the sense that she was sincere and had no understanding of the [[Canon law (Catholic Church)|church and the law]]. De Stogumber re-enters, screaming and severely shaken emotionally after seeing Joan die in the flames, the first time that he has witnessed such a death, and realising that he has not understood what it means to burn a person until he has actually seen it happen. A soldier had given Joan two sticks tied together in a cross before the moment of her death. Bishop Martin Ladvenu also reports that when he approached with a [[crucifix]] to let her see it before she died, and he approached too close to the flames, she warned him of the danger from the stake, which convinced him that she could not have been under the inspiration of [[Devil in Christianity|the devil]]. Epilogue: 25 years after Joan's execution, a [[Retrial of Joan of Arc|retrial]] has cleared her of heresy. Brother Martin brings the news to Charles VII. Charles then has a dream in which Joan appears to him. She begins conversing cheerfully not only with Charles, but with her old enemies, who also materialise in the King's bedroom. An emissary from the present day (the 1920s) brings news that the Catholic Church is to [[Canonization|canonise her]]. Joan says that saints can work miracles, and asks if she can be resurrected. At this, all the characters desert her one by one, asserting that the world is not prepared to receive a saint such as her. The last to leave is the English soldier, who is about to engage in a conversation with Joan before he is summoned back to [[Hell]] at the end of his 24-hour respite. The play ends with Joan ultimately despairing that mankind will never accept its [[saint]]s:
O God that madest this beautiful earth, when will it be ready to accept thy saints? How long, O Lord, how long?
==Criticism== [[File:Paris 75001 Place des Pyramides Jeanne d'Arc equestre by Frémiet S1.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Jeanne d'Arc (Frémiet)|Jeanne d'Arc]]'' statue at [[Place des Pyramides]], Paris by [[Emmanuel Frémiet]], 1874]] One historian at the time (1925) reacted to the play by arguing that it was highly inaccurate, especially in its depiction of medieval society.{{cite book | first = J. M. | last = Robertson | title = Mr. Shaw and "The Maid" | location =London | publisher = Cobdon-Sanderson | date = 1926 | page = 85 }}{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} Shaw states that the characterization of Joan by most writers is "romanticized" to make her accusers come off as completely unscrupulous and villainous.Preface to the play More general interpretation of Joan's character is to describe her as a rebel against general institutional authority, such as that of the Catholic Church and to the feudal system.{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2007/jul/12/theatre2 | title=Saint Joan: Olivier Theatre, London | work=The Guardian | last = Billington | first = Michael | date=12 July 2007 | accessdate=2009-01-18}} Contemporary comments have noted her particularly strong form of religious belief and how it borders on religious fanaticism.{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2007/jul/03/theatre | title=The shock of the old | work=The Guardian | last = Gardner | first = Lyn | date=3 July 2007 | accessdate=2009-01-18}} Tony Stafford discussed Shaw's use of imagery related to birds in the play.{{cite journal | last=Stafford | first=Tony J. | title=From Hens' Eggs to Cinders: Avian Imagery in Shaw's ''Saint Joan'' | journal=Rocky Mountain Review of Language and Literature | volume=40 | issue=4 | pages=213–220 | year=1986 | doi=10.2307/1566575 | publisher=Rocky Mountain Modern Language Association | jstor=1566575}} Frederick Boas has compared the different treatments of Joan in dramas by [[Henry VI, Part I|Shakespeare]], [[The Maid of Orleans (play)|Schiller]], and Shaw.{{cite journal | last=Boas | first=Frederick S. | title=Joan of Arc in Shakespeare, Schiller, and Shaw | journal=Shakespeare Quarterly | volume=2 | issue=1 | pages=35–45 | date=January 1951 | doi=10.2307/2866725 | publisher=Folger Shakespeare Library | jstor=2866725}} [[T. S. Eliot]], discussing the play after its premiere in London in 1924, wrote that although ''Saint Joan'' was not the masterpiece that some claimed it to be, the play "seems to illustrate Mr. Shaw's mind more clearly than anything he has written before." And although he credited Shaw with providing an "intellectual stimulant" and "dramatic delight", he took issue with his portrayal of the heroine: "his Joan of Arc is perhaps the greatest sacrilege of all Joans: for instead of the saint or the strumpet of the legends to which he objects, he has turned her into a great middle-class reformer, and her place is a little higher than [[Emmeline Pankhurst|Mrs. Pankhurst]]" (the militant leader of the British [[suffragette]]s).{{cite journal | authorlink = T. S. Eliot | last = Eliot | first = T. S. | title = A Commentary | journal = The Criterion | volume = 3 | date = October 1924 | pages = 1–5 }} ==Productions== Shaw's personal reputation following the [[World War I|Great War]] was at a low ebb, and it is thought that he wanted to first test the play away from Britain. The play received its premiere on 28 December 1923 at the [[Garrick Theatre (New York City)|Garrick Theatre]] on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] by the [[Theatre Guild]] with [[Winifred Lenihan]] in the title role.{{cite book|title=Twentieth-century English history plays: from Shaw to Bond|last=Harben|first=Niloufer|page=31|isbn=0-389-20734-9}} The London première, which opened on 26 March 1924 at the [[Noël Coward Theatre|New Theatre]], was produced by [[Lewis Casson]] and [[star]]red Shaw's friend [[Sybil Thorndike]], the actress for whom he had written the part.{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn3290514 |work = Digital Collections – Pictures | last = Guttenberg | first = Percy | title = Portrait of Sybil Thorndike as St. Joan in George Bernard Shaw's St. Joan |format = picture | publisher = [[National Library of Australia]] |date=c. 1924 |accessdate=2012-11-08}} Costumes and sets were designed by [[Charles Ricketts]], and the play had an extensive musical score, specially composed and conducted by [[John Foulds]]. Caught between the forces of the Church and the Law, Joan is the personification of the tragic heroine and the part is considered by actresses (see below) to be one of the most challenging of roles to interpret. It is usually played by very experienced actresses who are much older than the age of the character, a teenager. For a film version, Joan was exceptionally played by [[Jean Seberg]], who was 19. ===Notable St. Joans=== * [[Winifred Lenihan]] – [[Garrick Theatre (New York City)|Garrick Theatre]], December 1923 – April 1924 (Initial production) * [[Sybil Thorndike]] – London, March 1924 (Shaw wrote the play with her in mind) * [[Katharine Cornell]] – [[Martin Beck Theatre]], New York, March 1936 – May 1936 ([[Tyrone Power]] made a pre-Hollywood appearance) * [[Wendy Hiller]] – Malvern Theatre Festival, Malvern, England, July 1936 (honoring Shaw's 80th birthday) * [[Uta Hagen]] – [[Cort Theatre]], New York, October 1951 – February 1952 * [[Siobhán McKenna]] – [[Phoenix Theatre (New York)|Phoenix Theatre]], New York, December 1956 – January 1957, also came to England with this production. ([[Peter Falk]] appeared in a small part) * [[Joan Plowright]] – London, 1963 * [[Sandra Seacat]] (as Sandra Kaufman) – [[Atlanta Women's Club|Community Playhouse]], Atlanta, February 12 – 24, 1965 (directed by [[Michael Howard (American actor)|Michael Howard]], Seacat's erstwhile mentor, and featuring [[Actors Studio]] founding member [[William Hansen (actor)|William Hansen]] as [[Saint_Joan_(play)#Characters|The Inquisitor]], this was the opening production of Atlanta's first—and last—annual "Fine Play Season")Gray, Tom. [http://www.mediafire.com/view/pxnvfp2ixv02dp7/Gray%2C%20Tom.%20St.%20Joan%20May%20Be%20Theater's%20Best%20Effort.%20The%20Atlanta%20Constitution.%20October%2013%2C%201965.%20%20.png "St. Joan May Be Theater's Best Effort"]. ''The Atlanta Constitution''. October 13, 1965. Retrieved 2018-07-16. * [[Jean Seberg]] – television production, 1967 * [[Diana Sands]] – [[Vivian Beaumont Theater]], [[Lincoln Center]], New York, January 1968 – February 1968 * [[Lynn Redgrave]] – [[Circle in the Square]], New York, November 1977 – February 1978 * [[Imelda Staunton]] – London, 1979 * [[Frances de la Tour]] – London, 1984 * [[Imogen Stubbs]] – London 1994 * [[Jacqueline McKenzie]] -- [[Sydney Opera House]], [[Sydney Theatre Company]], 1995 * [[Anne-Marie Duff]] – [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]], London 2007{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2007/jul/15/theatre1 | title=Joan burns bright in a match made in heaven | work=The Observer | last = Clapp | first = Susannah| date=15 July 2007 | accessdate=2009-01-18}} * [[Amy Irving]] – sound recording, 2010 * [[Gemma Arterton]] – [[Donmar Warehouse]], London 2016{{Cite web|url=http://www.donmarwarehouse.com/whats-on/donmar-warehouse/at-the-donmar/2016/saint-joan#AzrOH7qMMqMrucxt.97|title=Saint Joan – Donmar Warehouse|website=www.donmarwarehouse.com|access-date=2016-09-11}} * [[Lisa Hogg|Lisa Dwyer Hogg]] – Lyric Theatre, Belfast 2016 * [[Condola Rashad]] – [[Manhattan Theatre Club]], New York 2018{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/condola-rashad-to-star-in-saint-joan-on-broadway|title=Condola Rashad to Star in Saint Joan on Broadway|website=www.playbill.com|access-date=2018-02-20}} Other notable Joans include [[Judi Dench]], [[Zoe Caldwell]], [[Elisabeth Bergner]], [[Constance Cummings]], Ann Casson, [[Roberta Maxwell]], Barbara Jefford, Pat Galloway, [[Sarah Miles]], [[Ellen Geer]], [[Jane Alexander]], [[Lee Grant]], [[Janet Suzman]], [[Maryann Plunkett]],https://www.nytimes.com/1993/02/01/theater/review-theater-getting-know-joan-who-saintly-shavian-just-bit-unlikable.html [[Eileen Atkins]], [[Kitty Winn]] and [[Sarah Snook]]. ==Adaptations== '''Films'''
{{main|Saint Joan (1957 film)|Saint Joan (1967 film)}} *In 1927, [[Lee de Forest]] filmed Sybil Thorndike in the cathedral scene from ''Saint Joan'' in a [[short film]] made in his [[Phonofilm]] sound-on-film process. *In 1957, the play was adapted for film by [[Graham Greene]], directed by [[Otto Preminger]], with [[Jean Seberg]] as Joan of Arc, [[Richard Widmark]], [[Richard Todd]], and [[John Gielgud]]. '''Stage''' *[[Lanford Wilson]]'s 2000 play ''Book of Days'' is a modern-day re-imagining of ''Saint Joan''. '''Sound recordings''' *[[Caedmon Records]] released a complete audio adaptation of the play in a four-record stereo LP boxed-set with full script booklet. It starred [[Siobhán McKenna]] as Joan, [[Donald Pleasence]] as The Inquisitor, [[Felix Aylmer]] as Peter Cauchon and [[Alec McCowen]] as The Chaplain. *[[Blackstone Audio]] released a full-cast recording starring [[Amy Irving]], [[Edward Herrmann]], Kristoffer Tabori, Gregory Itzen, Armin Shimerman, Granville Van Dusen, among others. The production, which was directed by [[Yuri Rasovsky]], won an [[Audie Award]] as Best Audio Drama of 2010. '''Opera'''
The play has also been adapted into an opera by composer Tom Owen.{{cite web | url = http://www.shef.ac.uk/concerts/springopera.html | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081223041445/http://www.shef.ac.uk/concerts/springopera.html | archivedate = 2008-12-23 | title = Spring Opera Productions | publisher = The University of Sheffield }} ==Awards and honors== ;Awards * 2010 [[Audie Award]] for Best Audio Drama * 2008 [[Laurence Olivier Award]] for Best Revival ;Nominations * 1993 [[Tony Award]] for Best Revival of a Play * 2018 [[Drama League Award]] for Outstanding Revival of Broadway or Off-Broadway Play * 2018 [[Tony Award]] for Best Actress in a Play – [[Condola Rashad]] ==See also== * [[Cultural depictions of Joan of Arc]] ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist}} ;Sources *Dailey, Jeff. [https://web.archive.org/web/20120302073957/http://www.oscholars.com/Shavings/Plays26/plays26.htm#_More_Shaw_in "The Villains Always Wear Red"] Oscholar.com 2007 Accessed August 7, 2010 * {{cite book | last=Shaw | first=Bernard | title=Saint Joan: A Chronicle Play in 6 Scenes and an Epilogue | location=London | publisher=Constable & Co., Ltd. | year=1924 | oclc=248014614}} ==External links== * {{IBDB show|7712|Saint Joan}} * [http://gutenberg.net.au/ebooks02/0200811h.html Full Text of the play] * [http://primary-sources-series.joan-of-arc-studies.org/PSS021806.pdf Primary sources about Joan's male clothing in context] * [http://www.joan-of-arc.org/joanofarc_life_summary_orleans.html Description of the physical Joan] * [http://muse.jhu.edu/cgi-bin/access.cgi?uri=/journals/annual_of_bernard_shaw_studies/v025/25.1bertolini.html Discussion on Shaw's character and attitude to war] * [http://www.cbsd.com/inventory.aspx?id=7495 Playing Joan interviews] {{George Bernard Shaw}} {{OlivierAward PlayRevival 2001–2025}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saint Joan (Play)}} [[Category:1923 plays]] [[Category:Broadway plays]] [[Category:Laurence Olivier Award-winning plays]] [[Category:Plays based on real people]] [[Category:Plays by George Bernard Shaw]] [[Category:West End plays]] [[Category:Works about Joan of Arc]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Joan of Arc]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Gilles de Rais]] [[Category:British plays adapted into films]]
